name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the report by Notis Marias, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the work of the Committee on Petitions in 2016, pursuant to Rule 216 (7) of its Rules of Procedure (2017/2222 (INI)) (A8-0387 / 2017)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the shadows for their cooperation in drafting the report, which will be put to the vote today, a report on the work of the Committee on Petitions for 2016. I would also like to thank the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions, as well as my colleagues in the ECR Secretariat. As you know, the right to petition the European Parliament is enshrined in the European Treaties. This is an important right which derives from European citizenship itself. Of course, every citizen, according to the Treaty, but also every permanent resident of the European Union has the right to report on an issue which falls within the scope of the European Union. At the political level, this right is particularly important, as it enables citizens to express themselves, linking them to the European Parliament itself. Besides, the Committee on Petitions is the only committee in which the citizens themselves participate, as they intervene as petitioners. In this sense, it is also an indirect mechanism for monitoring the application of European Union law, and so there is an interconnection with the Commission itself and, of course, we will listen with particular interest to the views of the Commission, Mr Vella in this case, on how the Commission views the functioning of the Committee on Petitions. But I would say that Mr. Timmermans's frequent involvement in our work also gives us a clue as to how and at what level this cooperation should exist, a cooperation that is definitely important, because citizens raise important issues through petitions, such as are the right to free movement, issues related to the implementation of fundamental rights, issues concerning the rights of the child and people with disabilities, but of course the concerns of citizens for the protection of the environment are also expressed through the Committee on Petitions, which also has a direct relationship and close cooperation with the European Ombudsman. So I would say that the issues that occupied in 2016 but also concern the Committee on Petitions this year are important. In particular, we were concerned about the Marrakesh agreement on the rights of the blind, the rights also arising from the Istanbul agreement, the rights of the child, and we had received many reports of Brexit, because the people are worried, especially its citizens. European Union, what will happen to their rights after the United Kingdom leaves the European Union. An important issue that concerned us in 2016 was German compensation, an issue which, as you know, I have raised since the first moment of my election here in the European Parliament, since there is a demand from Greece, which is determined by its decisions. of the 1946 peace agreement, which set out Germany's obligation to make war reparations to Greece, to repay, of course, the forced occupation loan, and to compensate the relatives of the victims executed by the Nazi occupation troops. This issue was raised with the report of the fighters of the National Resistance and the Democratic Army of Greece, on 2214/2014. With my intervention, this petition in September 2015 was deemed admissible and then the procedure for discussion was opened. We made a lot of efforts in order to put this specific report on the shelf, not to discuss it, and unfortunately the majority of the coordinators of the Committee on Petitions on 8.9.2016 considered that this issue allegedly does not fall within the competences of the European Union and closed the file. . This was therefore mentioned in paragraph 16 of my report. Unfortunately, the European People's Party, the Socialist Group and the Liberals did not accept this position, they tabled an amendment and this view has been deleted through the report. But this What was unprecedented, Mr President, was that the report was also asked to change. This never happens and so any reference to German reparations has been removed from the report. Beyond that, this is an issue that has preoccupied us, because otherwise there are no particular problems in the report that we will discuss. We have to mention this because it is important. I am waiting for the opinions of colleagues and I reserve the right, in the 2 minutes I have after the end of the discussion, to answer.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me begin by thanking the rapporteur Mr Marias for his accurate and comprehensive report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2016. I also take the opportunity to thank Ms Wikström and the whole Committee on Petitions for its important work. Like its predecessors in previous years, the report gives evidence of the broad spectrum of issues that petitioners bring to the Committee on Petitions’ attention each year, and of the committee’s efforts to ensure that the voices of those petitioners are heard. The Commission shares Parliament’s view that the right to petition is both a fundamental right of all EU citizens and a key element of participatory democracy, allowing for citizens’ active engagement in the fields of EU action. Petitions are an effective channel for direct contact and an open dialogue on problems affecting citizens in their daily life, especially in this day and age where democracy requires new ways and means to connect the EU’s institutions to the citizens they serve. This is also another very important tool to understand the pulse of Europe. Citizens often turn to the committee as a last resort because they feel that they have exhausted all other avenues and we – I mean both the Commission and Parliament – can demonstrate that we listen to their concerns and take them seriously, by offering proper responses and showing existing solutions at European or national level. This is a concrete example of how we can collaborate to restore citizens’ confidence and trust in the European project. As the report points out, our institutions have built good working relationships in recent years when it comes to handling petitions. Of the petitions declared admissible by Parliament in 2016, more than two-thirds were referred to the Commission for an opinion. In return, the 900 replies that the Commission sent back to Parliament in 2016 testify to our engagement to support the critical work of the Committee, which the Commission takes very seriously. All Commission replies are widely consulted among services, and suitably ranked officials with expert knowledge of the issues discussed are there to assist in the Committee’s meetings with the aim of providing the most meaningful and up to date information in a timely manner, as your report also recognises. I note the report’s insistence on providing ever better answers, and to be sure there is always room for improvement and the Commission will recommit itself to improving wherever we can in our effort to provide meaningful answers in a timely manner. I am therefore pleased to reaffirm the commitment of the Commission to keep up our good collaboration and to bring forward the EU added value in the resolution of petitioners’ concerns. Let me turn specifically to one of the issues raised prominently in the report by Mr Marias, namely the implementation of EU legislation. The Commission attaches particular importance to acting firmly and quickly when infringement proceedings are launched, especially when they obstruct key EU policy objectives. To this goal, the Commission adopted, in its communication ‘EU law: Better Results through Better Application’ of December 2016, a new approach to infringement policy that is more strategic, effective and proportionate. Moreover, it will also not automatically rely on the EU Pilot mechanism unless we see it as particularly useful on a case-by-case basis. Another concrete step to enhance transparency of decisions on infringement procedures is the centralised platform on our Europa website where the Commission proactively disseminates information on infringements. The Commission will continue to provide Parliament and the public with comprehensive information on monitoring the implementation of EU legislation and its follow-up. However, this needs to be done while respecting confidentiality obligations towards Member States in infringement procedures, as recognised by the European Court of Justice. The report also touches upon a number of other important issues, for which the views of Parliament and the Commission largely converge. Let me only mention the high priority in preserving citizens’ rights after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union, or the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities. I will however, Mr President, end my remarks by once again thanking Mr Marias for his is very helpful report. I look forward to hearing the views of the honourable Members in the debate.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work. Except, of course, for this obsession with German debt, he did his job very well, I think. This is an important report, which highlights the highlights of our activities over the past year. The work of the Committee on Petitions has improved a lot and gained in efficiency since the introduction of the new administrative procedure in 2014. Indeed, it is essential that the Parliament processes petitions and provides a response to citizens in a timely manner. reasonable time. This requires focusing on the petitions that are eligible. Another point on the functioning of our commission: the working groups. These should have a well-defined mandate with the objective of facilitating the processing of petitions. The network of the PETI commission is an essential tool which would benefit from being better known because it makes it possible to make the link between petitions and legislative work within Parliament. We have dealt with essential topics for petitioners this year, one of those topics being Brexit. Our committee is a fervent defender of citizens' rights. Whether it is British people or other Europeans, their concerns are legitimate and we must do everything to ensure that they are successful. There is also the European Citizens 'Initiative, which must now be used optimally to increase citizens' confidence in the European institutions. Cooperation with the European Commission and the Member States is essential for the processing of petitions, and that is why we ask to be informed more and on a regular basis about the infringement procedures.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur. 2016 was an important and varied year in the Committee on Petitions (PETI). This report highlights the important work that the PETI Committee has done in being a voice for citizens’ concerns. Thanks to the secretariat and to all of the Petitions team in the European Parliament for their hard work in ensuring that that voice can be heard.  MEPs across the European Parliament should take our work more seriously. This is the place where personal stories of EU action, inaction and legislation are heard, as people talk about the EU needing to re-engage with the public; why not better use the tools we already have to do that? The number of petitions received shows that citizens care about their right to petition. We have to do better in outreach, and we need the resources to be able to meet their expectations. This report highlights ways to make the Petitions Committee more accessible in the future, to allow more people to directly present their cases through the use of technology, such as videoconferencing. Of the petitions we received, many were related to Brexit, both UK citizens living in the rest of the EU and citizens from the rest of the EU living in the UK, as well as raising concerns about the future of their rights, as well as UK citizens angry about losing their EU citizenship. Citizens are already feeling the cold effect of Brexit and this Parliament must listen attentively to their concerns and defend them actively.  2016 was also the year when the new committee guidelines came into play. We in the S&D Group welcome the new method of working as it is based on full consensus across the political groups and a common understanding which adds to the democratic way we work inside our committee. I would remind the EPP that previous administrative rules were never endorsed by the committee, despite their attempts to include reference to them in amendments today. This report is a fair reflection of our work, and therefore I call on MEPs to support it.

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, I do not want to repeat all the good things which have already been said by Mr Marias, who very thoroughly described the topics we had to deal with, and also Mr Vella from the Commission side, and other colleagues who rightly said this a good channel, maybe the best channel here in this House, of how democracy is working.  I was supposed to speak on behalf of the ALDE Group, but I believe that true democrats will forgive me: I am going to speak on behalf of aliens, and these aliens have nothing in common with Mr George Lucas, the famous director. Aliens are people who have got, in Estonia and Latvia, a passport which is called an Alien’s Passport. They submitted a petition 18 months ago. In this report, one big political group made this petition a red line for them. We have 7% of non-citizens in Estonia and 12% of them in Latvia, and in order not to discuss the topic there were circulating huge amounts of letters containing huge amounts of lies.  The problem for us, for liberals and for me, as a representative of those people, is that we never reached the substance in this discussion. So I will use the opportunity and just say it is not true that these people vote for Putin. They do not vote in any country. They have no voting rights. It is not true that they serve in the Russian Army. They do not serve in any army. It is not true that to get Estonian citizenship they have to speak Estonian at elementary level. They have to speak Estonian B1, which is enough to study at university in any foreign country. So the problem is that we avoided this discussion. In the very beginning, when I came to the European Parliament, I was very happy that we have a really high political culture here but this petition is the thing which I really cannot accept.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. president. Last year I was the rapporteur for this report presented by Mr Marias today and, after a year, the truth is that the criticisms we have are still fundamentally against the Commission. We reiterate, once again, that you give more clarity to your answers, both written and oral. You must also give us more information on the proceedings opened against the States, within the confidentiality of which you speak. They also have to take us into account for the reform of the European citizens' initiative and, furthermore, we demand that, once and for all, the Commission make the precautionary principle prevail, especially in matters of the environment and also in health. What for if this principle has not been established? Because we continue to see continuously in the commission how in many countries, also in mine, in Spain, projects are cut up and environmental impact studies are cut up in the same way that access to information or citizen participation is violated - such as the famous Aarhus Convention. I also remind you that, without this precautionary principle, other essential principles such as legal certainty or subsidiarity cannot be guaranteed, without speaking of course of irreparable environmental damage. Do we have to wait, as always, for disasters to occur and for the completed events and that there is no solution afterwards? Please apply the principle.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr. President, yesterday, December 13, marked the 74th anniversary of the Holocaust, ie the execution of all the men and boys of the martyrs of Kalavrita in Greece by the Nazi occupation troops. One of the dozens of holocausts, the thousands of crimes of Nazism in Greece, for which, despite the decisions of international organizations, Germany never paid reparations. And yet, the majority of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions, taking advantage of the SYRIZA government's refusal to take a stand, did not investigate the report submitted by the National Democratic Resistance Fighters Union of the Hellenic Democratic Army in collaboration with the Communist Party of Greece, but deleted from the Commission minutes even that such a report has never been made. This is what you call democratic control. It is not a simple mistake, it is historical audacity! This is how the European Union rewrites history: with distortions, inventions of imaginary facts, silencing of the real. This is how the far right, Nazis, gold diggers, nostalgic Hitler, the armed hand of this system against the people, get courage. As much as various people in here want and insist, memory is a weapon in the hands of the people and we will not give it up.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I have five points to make. First: The Petitions Committee can look back on a successful year this year as well. I would also like to thank the secretariat and the PETI chair, Mrs Wikström, for this. Secondly, on the rapporteur: Mr Marias has done a very good job 99% of the time and not one percent. He said it himself, his problem is German reparation costs. Well, colleague Marias, I like consistent colleagues, but sometimes your consistency tends to be stubborn. I think that the plenary will vote on the report today in such a way that the report will be tidy again, also in your interests, so that your 99%, where you have done a good job, will then also be in the minutes. Point three, responsibilities: we should have the courage in the Petitions Committee to decide on responsibilities more quickly. That is good for the petitioners. My motto is: better a quick bad news than a petition process lasting several years with the same answer. Fourth, abuse: my colleagues will add it. Unfortunately, again this year we have seen a tendency for some groups to actually abuse the Committee on Petitions on certain issues. That also has to do with responsibilities. We in the Petitions Committee are simply not responsible for reparation costs or citizenships. That would be the first clear answer. And fifth, Network: This is the new invention. We hope that we can expand this further. The experience with the other specialist committees could be the petitions committee premium segment. We often have petitions where we understand the petitioner, but legal regulations speak against it. Here one could improve the legal regulations with the specialist committees.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Notis Marias, and Jude Kirton-Darling, our shadow rapporteur, who brought all of our contributions to this activity report of the Committee on Petitions. This commission, on which I would like to dwell a little bit, although it is non-legislative, is essential for our institution because it ensures a fundamental right, guaranteed by our founding pact - the treaties - which is that of addressing petitions when the right that we, legislators, vote here is not respected or that it calls for adaptations. This right is an essential link with our fellow citizens and civil society and it requires the mobilization of all actors so that petitions are dealt with correctly and with diligence. To this end, we reviewed the working methods of the Committee on Petitions in 2015 and they are working well. I therefore think that we must reject the amendments which would put a straitjacket on our activity and limit this democratic right to petition. If all the institutions must be mobilized - this Parliament, the first - there is one which must adhere to a particular requirement, it is the European Commission, because as guardian of the Treaties, it has the power to open infringement proceedings and to prosecute Member States for infringement, where appropriate, before the Court of Justice. This power is also a responsibility vis-à-vis our fellow citizens who do not necessarily have the means to go to court. It is therefore also a responsibility towards this Parliament, as co-legislator, to ensure that European law is correctly applied and to ensure the proper functioning of European democracy. It is for these reasons that we ask the European Commission to ensure, too, diligent treatment of the petitions that we send to it as well as the utmost firmness in the possible initiation of infringement proceedings.It is about the proper functioning of European democracy and respect for the texts that we vote on here as legislators.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, petitions are one of the few instruments where the institutions come into direct contact with citizens. The Committee on Petitions, in this context, acts as a check on EU policies as they are implemented in each Member State. Moreover, I think that, by analysing the petitions received, Parliament can use this information effectively to better understand the legislative process of the European Union and to prepare better legislation, but also how this legislation reflects on the lives of European citizens. The right to petition is a fundamental right. It is a basic element of a functioning participatory democracy which, when acted upon with fairness and transparency, can contribute not only to a consolidation of representative democracy, but also to enhancing the stature of Parliament as an institution in the public eye. I think the involvement of citizens in this action, where we directly connect them to Parliament, has a positive impact on the citizens. I think they perceive their Parliament as a meaningful place of interaction. In the end, I think we can do better. I think that with the Petitions Committee we can act together to strive to improve our support to citizens in the future.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!My question is more related to the fact that we will have a new Science Media Hub in Strasbourg from January 1st.The Science Media Hub has the task of better communicating what is happening on a European level.Is there a possibility here that the Petitions Committee can make better use of this instrument in order to be able to better present the results that we have via the European Parliament's Research Service to the citizens?

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: blue-card answer. – This is an excellent point. I think visibility and proper transparency – the proper transfer of information – is crucial. So in our work it is essential to make sure that our citizens know as much as possible. If we do that, then we make everything much easier.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Mr President, the Committee on Petitions empowers EU citizens with the right to bring to the Parliament issues which are important to them in their everyday lives and to have their concerns specifically addressed by the committee members. The right to submit a petition to the European Parliament builds an important bridge that needs to be suitably protected and promoted. The Petitions Committee plays a vital role in reconnecting the EU with European citizens and in reinforcing the democratic legitimacy and accountability of the EU decision—making process. However, it should be noted that the number of petitions received is still not satisfactory when compared to the EU’s population. Greater efforts are needed to increase awareness of, and to promote, the right to petition and the work of the Petitions Committee. I agree that there should be more communication through the press and social media in order to enhance awareness of the services offered by this committee. Furthermore, an efficient response time to citizens’ petitions is paramount and assists in enhancing the importance of citizens to the European Union.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - President! As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Petitions, I would like to say that I consider it important for the Committee on Petitions to report annually to the European Parliament, as it is the only committee that has daily contact with the citizens of the European Union. I would like to congratulate my colleague Marias, the document he has produced is really good. I would like to mention three things in this regard. Most importantly, I feel that we feel that the efficiency of PETI’s work has increased. This is the result of good teamwork, which has led to an increase in the number of petitions discussed, despite statistics showing an increase of almost ten per cent in the number of petitions submitted last year. The second important thing is that we feel that PETI's prestige in front of the citizens has also increased. We experience this during negotiations, during fact-finding visits, and during frequent hearings. This is a very important job with the citizens of the European Union. It is interesting to note that the Brexit negotiations have not yet begun, and we have already received hundreds of petitions concerning the rights of European Union citizens. Thirdly, I would like to ask the European Commission to pay more attention. Sometimes we feel that cooperation is slow. I would like to ask the Commission for more empathy, because let us not forget that the trust of the citizens of the European Union is at stake. I therefore thank my colleagues and the secretariat for their work and ask for further support from the European Parliament.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: – Mr President, I highly value the work of the Committee on Petitions in order to promote the legitimacy and credibility of this House and the European Union. However, I have to draw attention to Paragraph 29 for today’s vote, where we have a red line from the PPE Group in this case, because it is exactly about credibility and about the rightness of this issue. The issue is one which does not fall under any kind of responsibility of the European Union institutions, and in these times of fake news we are including the issue of faked facts about the privileges of the former Soviet immigrants in formerly occupied Baltic countries. By doing this, we are very much undermining the credibility of European citizens in this institution because, willingly or unwillingly, we are falling here into the trap of the Kremlin propaganda here which is promoted by some of our parliamentarians. Please bear this in mind.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the Committee on Petitions because, in the report, we can all see progress, especially in terms of the quality of the work, because this is not just about quantity. I strongly believe that the petition is the way in which citizens can reveal a problem, usually a problem that they have not been able to solve at national level. I also believe that this committee of ours, of the European Parliament, is very important and important is the way in which petitions are resolved and, in particular, the time in which the outcome of the petition is communicated. Citizens need to trust the Committee on Petitions and I believe that the work done by colleagues has been good and complex. It can be seen from the report that the number of petitions increased from 2000 to 2016. I also think that we need to analyze the issues and it can be seen that, compared to 2015, when in the first place there were petitions for environment and justice, here in 2016, most petitions are for the internal market. That is why I recommend that the Commission and the Member States monitor the application of the directives governing the internal market, because we all know that this affects the economic environment, but also the lives of citizens.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: - Thank you, Mr President.It is my duty to support Artis Pabriks' problem statement.Namely, there are a great many people in the European Union who, for one reason or another, are not nationals of any European Union country and their desire to vote in the European elections through the Committee on Petitions is undoubtedly an interesting but very insignificant issue for a very small group, so I would call for support.proposal from Mr Pabriks and to remove this sentence from the resolution.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this very relevant debate. I hope you will agree with me that the range of issues addressed during this morning’s debate provides proof not only of the importance of the right to petition in our Union but also of the importance of our collective efforts to respond to the concerns that citizens bring to our attention. My choice of the word ‘collective’ in this context is a delicate one, as both Parliament and the Commission have key roles to play in these areas.  I would like to comment on one area, that of environment and health, where it was said that this is one area which directly affects our citizens, and I totally agree. In fact, according to Europol and Eurobarometer, environmental standards and legislation are among the main areas of legislation most appreciated and acknowledged by EU citizens. There was also a mention of environmental impact assessments (EIAs) and I would like to comment that, every year, 16 000 EIAs and 34 000 screenings are carried out in the EU 28. In addition, whenever there is a risk of serious irreversible environmental harm and health risks, then the Commission always intervenes proactively.  Finally, let me reiterate that the Commission continues to attach great importance to the good working relationship built during these years with the Committee on Petitions and would like to reassure Parliament of its continued and strong commitment to cooperate closely together in the handling of petitions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, I think the debate has highlighted the key issues contained in the report or those that have been deleted with amendments which have unfortunately been accepted. Indeed, Mr Jahr, I am rigid on the issue of German reparations and I will remain so, because this is a very serious matter and you have to realize that the basis of post-war Europe is in the 1946 Paris Peace Treaty. The issue of German war reparations was also identified there. And 74 years after the Holocaust, the massacre of Kalavrita, which took place on December 13, 1943, the European Union must give a serious answer and the serious answer is firstly that we do not forget, secondly that there is a serious issue called "German war reparations "and concern Greece, concern Poland, possibly other countries, and this issue is not going to be closed. It is not going to end with a trick, or with amendments, or anything. I have put this up many times and I will continue to put it up and I tell you here: In the coming days I will submit a report on the issue of German compensation, so that I can see how you will handle it. But it turns out that you do not even want a public debate on this issue, because for four years you have been constantly rejecting my personal proposals for a public hearing, a public debate by the Committee on Petitions on the issue of German reparations and you are constantly rejecting it, the European People's Party , the Socialist Group and the Liberals. Why; What were you afraid of from the public debate and the public hearing? So I believe that this issue will always be relevant, because with tricks, with amendments, the historical memory is not erased. Therefore, it is a demand of the Greek people, a demand of the thousands, of the millions of victims of Nazism, that justice be done, and that is what you, who come from Germany, to have realized that.Therefore, this issue will remain open in the future.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place today at 12 noon.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The annual report on the activities of the Petitions Committee is overall satisfactory.Shareable is the highlighting on the one hand of the improvements to be made in the institutional response to the complaints received and, on the other hand, of the further enhancement of the right to petition.The aim is in fact that of a general increase in the influence of citizens in EU decision-making processes.It is fully underlined that petitions are a useful tool for identifying not only violations of EU law but also gaps and contradictions of EU law with respect to the objective of ensuring the protection of citizens' fundamental rights.Their participation and involvement are the main resource for building a more legitimate EU and more responsive to their needs and expectations.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item is the report by Bas Eickhout, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on a European Strategy for Low Emission Mobility (2016/2327 (INI)) (A8-0356 / 2017)

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, on this Thursday morning we are going to talk about the European Strategy for Low-Emission Mobility, which means of course talking about the transport sector – that is one of the more challenging sectors – in order to comply with the Paris Agreement. When we were getting to a deal in Paris, we knew that all the different sectors have to deliver their contribution,l and that is not so easy. It is nice to say yes to Paris, it is more difficult to implement it in specific sectors. For example, last night there were trilogues until about 5.30 on the effort sharing – where the transport sector belongs – but no deal was reached. This is just to show that words are nice, but deeds are more complicated.  What we are doing in this report is to give, as a Parliament, our reaction to the White Paper that the Commission has published on the future of low—emission mobility, which is a good start by the Commission, but in the end was very general on many issues, whereas in this report we are trying to become more concrete. Looking at all the different sectors, what does it mean if you implement Paris? The first important message is that the transport sector should be close to zero emissions by mid—century, which means that the Commission White Paper, looking at the future of transport, needs to be updated, and Parliament is also clearly asking for that. But of course it also means sectoral activity.  I think that there will be a lot about cars in the debate. As always, in the Parliament we love to debate about cars. I just want to warn my colleagues that there is much more in the report than just that. What the car and the future of cars mean for CO2 emissions and for a mandate on zero-emission vehicles will of course be discussed. The report makes some statements on this, but the legislative proposal that the Commission put forward at the beginning of this month on CO2 limits in cars is going to be the legislative work on that. What we further do in this report is to shine some light on all the different sectors and come up with different proposals, but one more overarching and important message that this report gives is that we have to get the pricing right. If we just look at the different modes of transport, we see that the different ways of pricing are unevenly distributed. One that springs to mind is the aviation sector. There too we know that, preferably, we will need global action, but it is also very important to realise that, in the end, European action also stimulates action at global level, as was happening at ICAO. That is also very clear. If Europe had not taken its step on ETS a couple of years ago, there would not have been a global deal in ICAO two years ago. I think that is also an important message.  The report does, of course, go further into infrastructural challenges and issues around logistics and digitalisation, looking at how these future technologies will provide options and opportunities. I think it is very important that the report also goes into the economic opportunities. If you go to a low—emission mobility transport, there are also opportunities for new sectors to thrive and to have future jobs. I think that is a very important message in this report as well. There will be some tight votes, I know that.  I want thank my shadow rapporteurs for their great work on it – I can see them all in this room – and I would also would like to thank Mr Zoffoli from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), who also actively contributed to the report with contributions from the ENVI Committee, bringing together a strong report. I hope this Parliament will send a strong message to the Commission to come forward with more legislative action to make sure that we will have near zero—emission transport by mid-century.   (Applause)

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sustainable low-emission mobility is one of the key elements of the wider transition to a new development model, which Europe needs to remain competitive and create new and good jobs. Greenhouse gas emissions from transport represent a quarter of total emissions, are constantly increasing and are the main cause of air pollution. The opinion of the ENVI commission, of which I was rapporteur, which was incorporated in full in the report in question, examines the emissions of all the main means of transport: cars and vans, heavy vehicles, airplanes, ships, in addition to the topic of overcoming first generation biofuels by 2030, taking into account indirect land use change and encouraging a broad market penetration of those advanced fuels that respect the principle of the waste hierarchy and strong sustainability criteria. In the case of cars and vans, ambitious CO2 targets are being asked for 2025 and to develop a road test to calculate real emissions. For heavy vehicles, an important novelty: after years of useless discussions, finally by 2018 we will have a regulation for the monitoring, certification and publication of data on emissions and consumption of heavy vehicles, and to follow a proposal for emission limits same. The Commission is also invited to adopt an ambitious action plan for placing electric vehicles on the market. Finally, we ask for a coordinated homologation and market surveillance system at EU level to overcome the shortcomings highlighted by the "dieselgate", reducing the compliance factor for nitrogen oxide emissions to 1 by 2021.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the invitation to discuss our European Strategy for Low-Emission Mobility. The Commission warmly welcomes Parliament’s report and I would personally like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Bas Eickhout, and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this report. As highlighted in President Juncker’s State of the Union address in September, we should strive to become the world leader in the fight against climate change. The transition to a modern and low-carbon economy is a key political priority for the Commission. We need to address this challenge of climate change and at the same time, we must strive to extend the competitive edge of our industries, generate sustainable economic growth and jobs, and drive innovation in clean technologies. Transport is responsible for almost a quarter of Europe’s greenhouse gas emissions and contributes significantly to air pollution. If we were to do nothing, the sector would become the largest emitter of CO2 emissions after 2030. Low-emission mobility is therefore absolutely essential to meet our commitments under the COP 21 Paris Agreement and also to meet the 2030 energy and climate goals we agreed on. A well-defined EU strategy for the transport sector is essential, and it must cover all three core areas: first, higher efficiency of the transport system; second, low-emission alternative energy for transport; and third, low and zero-emission vehicles. By making our transport network more efficient, we can reduce the energy consumed, cut journey times and better serve the end user. There is a massive potential to make this happen by encouraging multimodal transport solutions and digitalisation.  We have already adopted in the past months a series of measures to foster the attractiveness of the most environmentally friendly modes of transport, specifically railways and inland navigation. The Commission also proposed recently additional measures to avoid empty runs in road freight operations, as well as in favour of combined transport and public transport by buses and coaches. We count on Parliament to support those initiatives. On alternative energy however, it is not just about transport efficiency. The second area we are tackling is that of energy. Promoting alternative energy sources for transport is essential. At present, 94% of transport energy is still derived from oil. This means high emissions and dependency on imports. To speed up the transition to alternative energy, the Commission has proposed recasting the Renewable Energy Directive. We have a clear expectation that the proposed gradual reduction of conventional crop-based biofuels and increase of advanced biofuels will promote the development and deployment of innovative advanced renewable fuels.  We are also actively supporting the deployment of alternative fuel infrastructures, such as recharging stations for electric cars, with financial support, consumer information and standardisation activities. To stimulate electro mobility, it is crucial to ensure the interoperability of electric vehicle charging. Recharging an electric vehicle should be as easy as refuelling a conventional car. With regards to zero and low-emission vehicles, which brings me to the third area, EU fuel efficiency standards for cars and vans have proven to be a strong driver for innovation and efficiency in vehicles. But emissions need to be reduced even further. This is why the Commission proposed, as part of its second mobility package, ambitious and realistic CO2 emission targets for cars and vans, while incentivising the further deployment of zero and low-emission vehicles. We also proposed additional measures to speed up market uptake and to accompany public authorities’ efforts in this respect.  Action is also needed to reduce emissions from heavy duty vehicles and this will be proposed next year by the Commission in its third mobility package. Let me conclude: only together can we make the implementation of this strategy a success. With the Clean Energy for all Europeans package, the Europe on the Move package and the Clean Mobility package, the Commission has already put forward proposals covering a large part of the action agenda of this strategy. We now very much count on your continued constructive support to the low-emissions strategy and the various initiatives that flow from it. I am looking forward to our discussion.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to thank the rapporteur for the work he has done. It was a work that allowed all of us to deepen one of the most crucial, most decisive issues for the effective implementation of the Paris Agreement, COP21, but it was also a very frank work, in which some differences were highlighted . On these we have identified a method to reach the goal that interests everyone, that is to ensure that, even if starting from different cultural positions, COP21 does not remain a theoretical objective on paper. And unfortunately the analysis made also in his initial speech by the rapporteur is correct when he says that the Commission at COP21 has added messages that are sometimes too theoretical. Here, to give substance to all this, however, we cannot think that this concreteness depends on equally theoretical targets, we cannot think of inserting targets left and right, under the illusion that this is the way to attribute concreteness to COP21. We have to answer a fundamental question: transport is a central point for this question to be answered. We have emerging countries in which there is a growing demand for energy: India, at this moment, has implemented a policy that by 2040 will bring enormous investments in nuclear and renewables. But despite this, by 2040 India will still have 60 percent of its energy produced through coal. And today there are 400 million people in India who have no energy. So, no targets are made in Europe on electric cars to solve the problem that has not been solved by COP21. It is a global policy implemented within the WTO, in which we are given the opportunity to allow emerging economies to implement a development policy that responds to their energy demand through renewable, sustainable sources. Europe is not the protagonist of this response. Europe is a collaborator of a response that goes date globally.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Make our planet great again! So the request from French President Macron, alluding to the withdrawal of the USA from international climate diplomacy under US President Trump. In my opinion, the task of politics in this context is very clear: we have to create ambitious and clear framework conditions for citizens and for the economy. Our actions and our rethinking will have to be faster and more radical in order to keep global warming below 2 ° Celsius. The present report on low-emission mobility defines urgently needed goals in order to finally make progress in the transport sector. From the perspective of the social democratic group, I would particularly like to emphasize that we have succeeded in anchoring public transport as the central point of reference for sustainable mobility, defining ambitious modal shift goals and, with a view to international air and sea transport, the need for clear and fair price signals in all Highlight traffic modes. I ask all colleagues - I am making this appeal primarily to the People's Party and the Conservatives - to approve this report. There is an ambitious text to which we can refer as we work on legislative dossiers.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Dear Mr. Chairman, An enormous effort is required to reduce emissions in the transport sector, but it should be spread over the years. Any action should take into account the complex nature of the sector and the financial capacity of the Member States. The solutions proposed by Mr Eickhout are largely a "paper tiger" - at first glance impressive with their panache and certainly full of good intentions, but extremely difficult to implement quickly and effectively throughout the European Union, not only in some of the richest countries . In many cases, the price of an overly ambitious and hastily implemented low-emission transport policy will be paid by consumers in the costs of train or plane tickets, in expenses for the operation of private cars or in the price of every product that is brought to our neighborhood stores every day. For many companies that will have to replace their entire fleets of vehicles in order to meet restrictive climate standards, this can mean difficult costs to bear. It may even mean the end of their activities. The ECR Group cannot endorse a report that takes such little account of the financial implications of the proposed solutions. We are in favor of evolutionary solutions in the field of climate protection, adapted to the possibilities of the European economy, and a reasonable calendar. Unfortunately, this report does not meet these criteria.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - The Commissioner has just said it. If we do nothing, our mobility will become the largest source of greenhouse gas after 2030. It is therefore time for action, because we need to reduce emissions in Europe. Bas Eickhout's present report is balanced and ambitious, and it calls for action. Action to prevent new cars that emit CO2 from entering the European market after 2035. Action to roll out alternative fuels infrastructure across Europe. But also action to very consistently implement the principle that the user, the polluter pays, in transport, for road transport, but certainly also for other modalities such as aviation. Above all, let us all ensure that there is fair competition between the different modes of transport. This also means that the European Commission must go on an international trip to see what we can do about the exemption from VAT on airline tickets. Or what we can do to eventually just introduce excise duties on kerosene. Because why should I today have to pay VAT on a ticket for the train between Amsterdam and Paris, while I absolutely do not have to pay VAT for the same flight ticket between those two places? It simply cannot be explained to our citizens any longer simply because it is not fair. Consumers must be able to make a proper assessment based on a fair price. So, as a liberal, I fully agree that we are going to use price incentives to achieve sustainability. And, Mr President, that VAT exemption, but also the fact that there are no excise duties on kerosene, that is really just an example of something that we must tackle, precisely to bring about a turnaround. In conclusion, if we want to combat climate change, if we want to ensure a healthier living environment, then we must not only change start thinking about mobility, but above all act differently.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all, thank you to the rapporteur for a very important report. Transport is the source of more than 25% of greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union. At the same time, road transport produces more than 70% of greenhouse gas emissions in transport. Action is therefore needed in this area in particular, but at the same time efforts should be stepped up to reduce emissions in all transport sectors. In this context, I very much welcome the debate on the possibilities of electrifying transport, especially road transport. I would just like to point out that it would not be completely sensible to bet everything on one card. The debate should also be about the benefits of natural gases and biomethane, synthetic methane and liquefied petroleum gas. There are more options and we must take into account that they may continue to increase in the future. The debate on this subject must be factual, and especially realistic. We only need to ask for what is really achievable, and not a dream, and we also need to realize that with the development of alternative technologies, it is essential to build the necessary and necessary infrastructure. Without it, we can really only dream about it. Ladies and gentlemen, I sincerely hope that we do not neglect this issue. Air pollution in the European Union is responsible for more than four hundred thousand premature deaths every year, which I consider to be punishable and unacceptable. Here we must arrange a remedy.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, remember, not long ago, 2009-2010, Europe was the leader in the fight against global warming; we voted for a "climate-energy" package to set a course for our industry in terms of energy efficiency. But what have we been up to since? The numbers don't lie, alas! From 1990 to 2015, transport emissions increased by 16%. Since 2015, this is the only sector that is still growing. Transport accounts for 25% of greenhouse gases in Europe, including 70% for road transport. Air pollution causes 400,000 premature deaths in Europe every year. It leads to healthcare costs ranging from 330 to 940 billion euros per year. But we have to do something to change that. It is now! I remind you that your Commission made a commitment in 2011 that, by 2050, Europe will reduce CO2 emissions from transport by 60% compared to 1990. But how? This is where we have to be firm and we have a good track record with Mr Eickhout's report. Let’s stop funding diesel research, even the boss of Volkswagen is now saying so. Ditto for aviation: let's finally tax kerosene, stop this discounted VAT for tickets. On the contrary, let's put in place the “polluter pays” principle, particularly in road transport, by basing charges on distance and no longer on time. Let us set mandatory quotas for the production of clean vehicles for vehicle manufacturers rather than encourage them to do so. Unfortunately, reading your Commission's proposals on CO2 emissions from vehicles, it looks like Europe is waiting for the market to work wonders, while China has decided to produce a minimum of 10% of electric vehicles by 2019 It's nice to criticize Donald Trump on his climate commitments, but it's better than Europe take back leadership on climate change and become exemplary.That is why, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to follow our rapporteur, Mr Eickhout, in order to reaffirm firm ambition.Our goal must be clear: to actually reduce CO2 emissions from transport in Europe.Commissioner, I say it very firmly: we can no longer dance on a volcano, it is now or never.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report undoubtedly contains several positive elements, such as the attention to the promotion and development of alternative technologies for mobility, above all the electric one, the tax incentives dedicated to zero-emission vehicles and, in parallel, finally, the gradual elimination of economic incentives for fossil fuels. We are careful, however, so that the ambitious timelines within which to achieve all this can really materialize. It is also necessary to set intermediate steps in the short and medium term to be able to reach the 2020 and 2035 objectives. The indication to promote green public procurement is also good. Let us not forget, however, that the real transition to sustainable sources must consider both the direct and indirect aspects of using an energy source. For this reason, it would be much better to diversify sustainable mobility solutions, rather than focusing only on electric. And we also keep in mind how important public investments are in companies that have to approach a market, such as that of transport in Europe, which today still depends on petroleum products for more than 90 percent.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - I have seen very closely how rapporteur Bas Eickhout and the shadow rapporteurs have fought to deliver this report with good content.There are of course many warm words about greening, but when it comes to actions, the reality is a bit more complex than expected.We all want to have COP 21 realized tomorrow.But as I said before, life is stronger than doctrine and we have to be a little careful with the undertone of this report that it is going to be too one-sided in content.Electric cars in such a difficult city as Brussels, replacing all combustion cars with electric cars, that does not provide a solution to the traffic problem.It may hardly be said here, but the industry must switch.They need time for that and innovation.Citizens still hiccups at too high a price for that electric car.I would again like to draw attention to the classic modal shift from road and aircraft to rail and inland shipping.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! This is a very detailed report that shows all facets of transport and the potential for decarbonization. With this in mind: Many thanks to the rapporteur, Bas Eickhout, and to our shadow rapporteur, Mrs Graswander-Hainz. It is undisputed that traffic and transport in general must become cleaner, and it is not a contradiction in terms that on the one hand we can achieve the ecological goals, but on the other hand not only preserve the industrial base with its many hundreds of thousands of jobs, but also can also expand. However, this requires a coherent medium to long-term strategy. Mobility is a complex system in which each subsystem has its own functional logic. Urban traffic, for example, works differently from long-distance traffic, and car traffic works differently from truck traffic, air traffic or even shipping. In order to reduce emissions above all, we have to start in the cities, i.e. in urban traffic. Public transport and bicycles must become more attractive as a result, and we must also promote car sharing offers. Of course, digitization also brings great opportunities. In my opinion, digitization, digital applications and digital networking also offer a great opportunity for decarbonization. What do we do on the long haul? Long-haul transport - as we have repeatedly agreed in the European Parliament and put on paper with the Commission and the Council - must be shifted to rail. I would like to remind you again of the various white papers that have taken up this. If we are to succeed in this, the railways, in other words the railways, must also become more attractive, and they must be relieved of their tax burden. It must also be used throughout Europe in the infrastructure to be invested.And when we talk about infrastructure - Commissioner, you mentioned it - of course, alternative drive systems and alternative fuels need to be expanded.But I am surprised - let me say this again - that the Commission only came up with a communication in the mobility package and not with legislation.Either way, the report is good, it should be approved.Having said this, colleagues, dear President: I wish all of you Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - A steward is given control over something and must perform that task in a valuable and future-proof manner. To me, man is the steward of this creation and that responsibility requires us to combat the emission of pollutants, also in the transport sector. This is well described in Mr Eickhout's report and I will briefly focus on two good points and one less strong point. One, air traffic is a very polluting mode of transport and the colleague rightly calls attention to the pricing of kerosene and airline tickets. This is really necessary to continue the cleaner world, also in aviation. Second, freight traffic must also make the switch to cleaner and better, less polluting and sustainable, and that means plenty of room for innovation. So I am very pleased that paragraph 93 of the report makes a clear case for the Ecocombi. Fortunately, because the Ecocombi takes away a lot of kilometers that are made by smaller trucks. That is why it is great that the Ecocombi is featured so prominently. Three, as far as the railway paragraph is concerned, I find it very ideological. The many millions who went to rail for the modal shift have simply not worked. You can see that the modal shift of the railway did not materialize in the end. We need to look at more creative ideas, for example more connections between inland shipping and road transport. But in general, thanks to the rapporteur. Good report that the stewardship in the transport sector is doing well!

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The transport sector is still 95% dependent on fossil fuels today and is the only sector in which greenhouse gas emissions have actually increased over the past 25 years. I very much welcome our report on low-emission mobility. We provide important impulses for cleaner and more efficient mobility. I would like to emphasize two points in particular. First: If we want to find ecologically and economically sensible solutions, technology openness must be the guiding principle. There will not be a single solution for all forms of mobility. With all the strengths of the battery-electric drive, we shouldn't prematurely stifle all other innovations. Second, this strategy must not only be for city dwellers. We must also not forget the mobility needs of people in rural Europe. We must ensure affordable mobility in the future, especially where it is becoming increasingly difficult to provide public transport.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, I have no doubt that the intention to reduce emissions in transport is sincere and shared by the majority of this House, but it is an unsustainable roadmap if we make the green transition subject to the objective of reducing costs and increasing costs.profits of private companies.It is environmentally unsustainable, according to the logic of the market, very far from ecological sustainability, as we are seeing with the devastating expansion of biofuels or with the disproportionate growth of activities such as aviation.But it is also socially unsustainable, because consensus towards another production model cannot be generated through privatization or the precariousness of working conditions.We must break the strategy outlined in the White Paper and reconcile social transition and ecological transition in the transport policies of the European Union.This and no other is the way forward in Europe.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: - Mr President! We are now discussing how to change Europe's transport system in order to achieve a low-emission transport system, which is crucial if we are to be able to keep our promises from Paris. And then I want to highlight three proposals. The first proposal: distance-based charges for road freight transport. We must apply the market economy idea polluter pays. It is the person causing the problem who will pay for the solution of the problem. And then it must become more profitable to move freight traffic from roads to the train, and then the trucks will have to pay for their climate costs. It must also be the case that through tolls, it contributes to innovation and efficiency on the roads, because at present it is the case that our roads are filled with half-empty trucks. If we move more traffic from roads to trains, it will create space for those who actually have to use the roads in the future. Two: aviation has to pay for its climate impact. It is unreasonable for aviation to be able to escape the climate bill. Although it is good that the EU is now taking steps forward to start including aviation in the EU's emissions trading, we are still far from having aviation pay its full climate bill. We must include flights to and from airports outside Europe. We must also include the so-called the high altitude effects. This is because it affects the climate more when aircraft emit climate-damaging gases up in the air than down on the ground, but despite this, it is not included in the system at present. That's unreasonable. Three: major investments in sustainable infrastructure. For my two previous proposals, this means increased tax revenues that we can then use for massive investments in infrastructure. But if we are to meet our climate goals, from now on, all investments must go in a sustainable direction. This means more public transport, more railways, more high-speed trains and night trains. If we do this, we will make it easier for people in the future to do what is easy, cheap and smart for the climate.We Greens will fight for that.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Mr President, this report is all well and good if it continues to allow citizens the freedom to choose how they travel. It was after the 1997 Kyoto Agreement that our Chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced in 1998 that diesel cars should attract less vehicle tax than their petrol equivalent because of their better CO2 performance. Then in 2001 Mr Brown reduced vehicle tax on cars with low CO2. This was a major change to encourage the public to buy diesel cars. Yet now we are increasingly seeing dramatic change to what forms of transport we are to use.  The report also seeks to comprehensively reduce the attractiveness of private forms of transport. In other words, the EU is driving us out of our cars. In a nutshell: user pays, polluter pays. As regards ‘polluter pays’, what I do find positive is a move towards zero emissions based on consumer choice, and I stress consumer choice. What I do not find helpful is knee-jerk solutions that punish the driver before any proper infrastructure is in place.  Certainly, after watching the grand tour this weekend, it is clear that EVs are becoming more efficient and user-friendly, but many citizens do not have the financial capabilities to change their cars, and this needs to be addressed.  Just as citizens need time to prepare, so does the manufacturing industry. They still have forecourts full of petrol and diesel cars. Encouraging the development of hybrids will help aid the transition. UK-based Jaguar Landrover is one company, like others, who recognised the need to change and should be commended on their projects. They are reducing NOX and particles which are harmful. It is also wrong for the EU to force a change through financial penalties, dividing those who can afford and those who cannot.  While some parts of this report are moving in the right direction, it will be up to the UK Government – and it alone – to set the standards once we gain our independence in 2019. I finally leave my Christmas message to you all. The UK referendum ballot paper asked: Should the United Kingdom remain a Member of the European Union or leave the European Union? I hope the House of Commons respects their decision. They voted to leave. Merry Christmas, everyone.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! You really can't have anything against a European strategy for low-emission mobility. But let's not lose sight of proportionality with all the good approaches. We are on the right track by setting clear goals. What we don't need are European guidelines on how these goals are to be achieved. Rather, we need a technology-neutral approach that takes the entire footprint into account. Anyone who believes that only electric vehicles are zero-emission vehicles should ask themselves where the energy for them comes from and how they and their batteries are manufactured or disposed of. For me, setting a minimum number for the proportion of electric vehicles is disproportionate. Above all, we should refrain from penalizing certain modes of transport, because every mode of transport has its place, especially in intermodal transport. Basically, I do not believe in punishment, because it is more productive to create incentives for energy and environmentally friendly measures. That is why we do not need any kerosene tax and I cannot accept the general demonization of the diesel engine or combustion engines in general. Above all, we should concentrate more on the existing energy-saving possibilities than there are: the completion of the single European sky, the use of certain driver assistance systems or the further development of public transport systems.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to achieve the circular economy, the transition to low-emission mobility is essential. European transport systems meet the needs of mobility, but are also a source of countless problems, such as greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution in built-up areas. Furthermore, from 2030, the transport sector will become the main source of greenhouse gas emissions in Europe. We need a low-emission economy and follow a strategy for mobility that is more respectful of the environment and citizens' health. To achieve these goals, the transport sector needs to improve its efficiency through digital technologies, smart road pricing and multimodality. We also need to encourage the development and use of alternative energy and zero-emission vehicles. Ultimately, this transition will have a major impact on the labor market and will require a workforce with new skills, thus opening up new job opportunities for highly trained young people.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, we follow many of the considerations and recommendations that the report leaves, but it is clear that the report being discussed today could, should, have been more ambitious, namely in the need for defense and investment in sectors that already fall under low carbon mobility. , such as rail transport. If we understand the need for concrete measures to reduce emissions from the transport sector, we also understand that profound changes are needed in terms of spatial planning, regional and local development policies, distribution models, construction, management and maintenance public transport networks, infrastructures and services, public transport policies, planning and maintenance of road and road networks. This will only be possible within the framework of a break with the conditioning and policies of the European Union that allow, within the framework of the sovereignty of States, the definition of powerful public investment policies associated with public control of strategic sectors such as transport or energy .

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Mr President, I thank the rapporteur for his work. I endorse a number of its proposals, such as the requirement for clear transport price signals, in application of the "polluter pays" and "user pays" principles. However, this seems to me difficult to reconcile with the progressive liberalization of the various transport sectors within the European Union. It is also paradoxical to want to reduce emission rates while the European Union is promoting, through the "Trans-European transport network" program, the acceleration of the integration of the new Member States, as well as the achievement of an internal market, ideally barrier-free. Finally, I regret that no mention is made of the issue of worker mobility, unreasonably encouraged by the European Union. Indeed, from this worrying phenomenon stems a growing demand for mobility and therefore additional CO2 emissions, whereas it would be necessary, on the contrary, to protect employment in each country, but for that it would still be necessary to have the will. .

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Mister President! Let me begin with the rules of procedure. I thought the Commission's legislative proposals for lower emissions from cars and trucks had been on the table for weeks. Why don't we deal specifically and very quickly with this legislation today, also in terms of rapid environmental protection? Why do we waste our taxpayers' time and money today on wishful thinking and rather unrealistic goals? But thanks to the shadow reporters, especially to Massimiliano Salini, who has made green utopias a little more reality. We all want to move quickly into the emission-free age. But that is only possible if we give science and industry the freedom to innovate. That is also the political difference. We are talking about a design framework in which we provide legal framework conditions for new technical developments, open to technology, with companies, with citizens. The Greens and the Left do not want to shape. They want to ban and educate. You speak of a prohibition framework, quotas, cost savings and blinkers when choosing technology. Whether electric mobility or energy-efficient buildings - let's give sun, wind and water a chance to get into houses and cars as quickly and inexpensively as possible. Quite a few politicians can anticipate this. To do this, we need the innovative strength of business and science. To do this, we need a fair framework.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Mr President, the European Union is the most advanced region in the world in terms of environmental standards and the fight against climate change. That doesn't mean it should rest on its laurels. On the contrary, it obliges it to go further and further to lead the way and, above all, to ensure that all its Member States respect and apply the law. In this regard, the European strategy for low-emission mobility must be ambitious and comprehensive. The report we will be voting on in a few hours is demanding and realistic. It offers concrete courses of action. It is a document that lawmakers can rely on when translating our intentions into legally binding texts. Its field is too wide to go into detail in a minute and a half. This is why I will focus on one dimension that seems essential to me: the application of the "polluter pays" and "user pays" principles. Transport generates pollution, it is a fact, and even if we can try to reduce it, it will never be zero. Transport will always require ad hoc infrastructure, especially as vehicles are increasingly sophisticated. However, we can try to reduce pollution at the source, but for this to be done effectively, we need a minimum binding target for manufacturers, otherwise it will remain wishful thinking. It will also be beneficial for the competitiveness of the European automotive industry, as it will remain at the forefront of technological innovation. In addition, it appears essential to finance the infrastructures and the negative effects, known as “external costs”, by those who use them. Otherwise, the taxpayers are paying, and this is deeply unfair. These principles are also enshrined in the treaty. I therefore support their implementation for all vehicles in Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all the signatories to the Paris Agreement have committed themselves to limiting CO2 emissions. Electric transport systems, private or public, can help solve the main problems related to urban mobility through a reduction in emissions and the complete elimination of pollutants and noise from our cities. But the degree of sustainability of electric vehicles also depends on the use of electricity produced from renewable sources, thus becoming part of a more complex system. The transition to low-emission mobility therefore constitutes not only an opportunity for manufacturers and suppliers in the automotive, rail, maritime and aviation sectors, but also and above all a challenge to rethink our energy supply system as a whole. The transition to low-emission mobility needs new commercial, industrial and employment models, which foster innovative partnerships between large companies, SMEs and startups, giving rise to that new industrial revolution in which Europe has invested and in which it is now. at the forefront, thanks to his talents and professionalism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the report we are discussing is really very interesting because it raises the serious issue of gaseous emissions. This is an issue that should concern us, especially in the field of transport. But in order for change to take place, investment is needed, because these changes require significant technological developments. New infrastructure is needed. To have these changes in the railway sector, you realize that huge costs are required. The same if we will have changes in the shipping and aviation industry and especially in the automotive industry. I think it is an opportunity to pave the way for new investments, to pave the way for technological developments, and this report forms a framework that we could follow along the way.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I am a member of the TRAN Commission and I think there is a need to improve transport mobility, obviously taking into account reducing emissions, because statistics show that 25% of European Union emissions are from transport and 70% from road transport. I am glad that the report focused on urban transport, where we can make a major contribution to reducing emissions, and I think it is important to move to alternative fuels first at this level. We know that, according to the World Health Organization, road traffic noise is the second most common stress factor in the environment. There is therefore a need for a transition to environmentally friendly transport; therefore, investment is needed in research, in the automotive industry, in order to have efficient and non-polluting means of transport. The 2011 White Paper on Transport makes it very clear that we need a sustainable mobility policy and that we need to rely on a wide range of policy instruments to ensure an efficient transition. I appreciate, Commissioner, that you mentioned that we need to set realistic targets.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for their comments, and I would like to underline that the low-emission strategy will bring significant benefits in addressing the environmental footprint of transport in a comprehensive and graduated manner. The transport sector has to contribute its share of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. There is no doubt about that. The process to the low-emission strategy will also contribute to making our industry stronger and more competitive, and it will help clean up the environment for citizens and improve their quality of life through better air quality in cities and reducing congestion.  I agree with the point raised about urgency. Yes, we need to act, and we need to act now. We have already initiated a series of initiatives to support the move to lower emissions. Member States and local authorities, educational and research institutes, as well as producers and investors can all provide much-needed incentives.  One of the comments referred to the Commission’s approach to alternative fuels as only a communication and not as a legislative proposal. As specified in Directive 2014/94 on the deployment of alternative fuels, by the end of 2018 the Commission will present an action plan on alternative fuels infrastructures. We presented this action plan in November of this year. Regarding a legislative proposal amending the directive, this is foreseen for before the end of 2020 if the Commission considers the need for it.  A number of speakers also mentioned the importance of addressing aviation and the maritime transport sector. In order to effectively address emissions from international sectors, such as aviation and maritime, global solutions are needed. The EU is fully committed and strongly contributing to the ongoing processes for reaching effective and ambitious measures within the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and the International Maritime Organisation (IMO). For the Commission, this is a priority.  There was also a mention ofthe need for horizontal initiatives or horizontal enablers, and I can refer to a number of initiatives that are in place which should strengthen the impact of the steps outlined above. For instance, advancing the electromobility update by encouraging consumers to charge batteries at off-peak times through new rules for electricity market design. In addition, there are preparations for an EU strategy on research, innovation and competitiveness that should bring together energy technologies, transport and industry and facilitate the development of energy storage solutions, such as the next generation batteries, and focus more on research into advanced bio and synthetic fuels.
