Rules for a Digital Single Market should set standards for using digital technologies in transport and ensure free flow of data. The shift, as already mentioned by Mr Eickhout, to low-emission mobility will also have an impact on jobs in the transport sector, which currently account for 15 million or 7% of EU jobs, by requiring new skills. This challenge has been taken up in the New Skills Agenda for Europe. This strategy therefore aims to develop a horizontal enablers’ programme as well, in order to create the right framework conditions for innovation and investment in the low-emissions sector.  I would like once again to thank the European Parliament for this constructive cooperation on this file. I would also once again like to thank Mr Eickhout and the shadow rapporteurs. We all look forward to a positive vote.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to say thank you to the Commissioner, and also to colleagues, for the very interesting debate we have had this morning. One thing that is striking is that some of my colleagues read ‘prohibition’ in this report and they read that we are favouring one certain technology specifically. I would like to ask them where they read that. When we are putting a mandate on zero—emission vehicles it is probably you who then reads ‘electric cars’. Maybe that says something about your obsession rather than what is in the report, because it is just a mandate on zero—emission vehicles. Anything that can comply with that will deliver. It does not say ‘electric cars’. Point out to me where ‘electric cars’ is explicitly mentioned. I think it is a bit of a preoccupation with some of my colleagues that they read ‘electric cars’ everywhere, as if that is the biggest enemy.  I think, in the end, we have to clean up our air, we have to lower emissions and it is possible. I really want to stress that it is possible and, if we do it in time, it will make sure that the jobs we have will remain in Europe. If we do not do it, the rest of the world will move ahead and we will start importing their techniques instead of producing them ourselves. I think that what the Brits would say is ‘penny wise, pound foolish’. I would like to stress that we really have to be careful not to make that mistake.  For the rest, I really would like to thank everyone for the cooperation. I am looking forward to the vote. I would like to say thank you very much to the Commission, but you say we have all the proposals on the table, though you also know very well that some of these proposals are not so ambitious at all. In the end, Paris implementation also requires the Commission to come forward with proposals that really deliver on that, and I therefore plead to my colleagues not only to accept this report, setting nice targets, but when we are talking about legislative proposals that we also really will make sure that they will deliver on what is needed to implement Paris. Thank you once more. I am looking forward to the vote and future debates.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 December 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written.- All economic sectors must step up their efforts so that we can meet the Paris climate agreements.Industry, energy, buildings, agriculture, they all need to emit considerably less greenhouse gases.A fortiori, the transport sector must take measures, because transport is one of the few sectors that has started to emit more CO2 in recent years.Seven EU countries, including Belgium and the Netherlands, have already given a shot.They want CO2 emissions from cars to be reduced by at least 40% over the next decade.This is only possible if we accelerate the switch to electric cars.Shipping and aviation also have to make much greater efforts, because CO2 emissions are increasing exponentially.It is good that we as the EU continue to exert international pressure to further tackle greenhouse gas emissions from ships and aircraft.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – This is the time for innovation. The time for further investments, that can support a proper transition to a low—carbon economy and to low—emission alternatives in transport for the years to come. Citizens are getting increasingly aware of the health impacts of air pollution and our countries have committed themselves to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This is the time to act. In this sense it is positive that an increasing number of countries are considering ending sales of new diesel and petrol cars: France and the UK by 2040, India by 2030, Austria by 2030, Malta probably by 2030, the Netherlands and Norway already by 2025. An irreversible shift to low—emission mobility is the way forward. For citizens it will mean cleaner air in our cities and eventually cheaper electric vehicles that can be affordable to all. For our economy it means more investment in innovation, research and development. Let’s be the game changers. Let’s push for improved consumer information. Let’s empower citizens and decision makers to help push forward a much needed behavioural change. Only through proactive action can we help increase a market for zero emission vehicles across the EU. Proactive action is what we need at this point in time.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I consider the implementation of the strategy of the lowest possible mobility to be a goal to be supported. I can agree with many of the proposals in the parliamentary report, such as the increased use of natural gas, including LNG, CNG in certain segments of transport. However, there are some proposals in the parliamentary report with which I largely disagree. An example is the article which seeks to introduce a minimum target for manufacturers for the share of zero-emission cars. I believe that mandatory regulation is an excessive interference in the economy, in the business decisions of economic operators. Moreover, for some players, the regulation could be a significant disadvantage in international competition. Without such measures, incentive competition between manufacturers is expected to emerge, as there are now examples. Another point is the introduction of distance-based charging for passenger cars. The Commission material also makes reference to this. While I fully support this principle with regard to lorries, which is a practical representation of the polluter pays principle, I think that with regard to passenger cars, there are other considerations that could override that approach. I also ask the Commission to change its position.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The aim of low-emission mobility must be to promote and introduce forms of safe, affordable and efficient transport that lead to zero emissions and thus greater protection of the environment and public health.In particular, the Union must seek ways and conditions to encourage innovation to encourage manufacturers to develop and manufacture low-emission vehicles and to give consumers interest and confidence in such vehicles.The fight against climate change requires the Union to work with other countries around the world to achieve this goal, in particular with the actors of the Paris Agreement, who are aware of the seriousness of the effects of emissions on the quality and existence of life on Earth.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - The emission reduction justified by the use of biofuels is a deception. The current biofuels policy, although its use is limited to 7%, will increase GHG emissions in the transport sector. If we take into account the greenhouse effect emissions derived from indirect land use change, biodiesel emissions are on average 80% higher than those of fossil diesel. Although bioethanol has some reductions, it does not meet the minimum requirements required by the Renewables Directive. Using the land to grow raw materials for fuel is very energy inefficient. While a football field planted with corn can fuel 2.4 cars for a year, the same stretch of photovoltaic panels could generate annual power for 260 cars. It should be added that, in the absence of sustainability criteria, the use of palm oil for biodiesel in Europe has increased by 600%. While in 2010, 8% of total palm oil imports were used in transportation, in 2016, the figure reached 46%. The sad conclusion is that, unknowingly, European drivers are the biggest consumers of palm oil.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - Road transport accounts for 70% of total transport emissions. So if we are to focus on a specific area in the fight against climate change, we are moving in the right direction. The report's objectives are broadly in line with our long-term interests, but in some respects they are ahead of time. I agree with the support for the production of low-emission cars, but I am not in favor of mandatory quotas. We should take measures to motivate manufacturers to produce low-emission vehicles and consumers to purchase them. By enforcing it, we could jeopardize technological progress and natural competition. I also do not support the idea of ​​the mandatory introduction of toll systems for passenger cars as well. Charges for the use of motorways should reflect emissions, but this can be ensured in other ways. On the contrary, I would like to emphasize the need to increase consumers' motivation to use more environmentally friendly modes of transport, such as public transport, cycling, car-sharing, etc. Therefore, there is a need to ensure affordable public transport and information trip planning. I can also imagine better cooperation between Member States in this area. A good proposal is to create a voluntary information platform that would connect national databases for searching for connections.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on five motions for resolutions on freedom of expression in Vietnam, in particular the case of Nguyen Van Hoa (2017/3001 (RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, in recent years Vietnam has made great economic strides, but human rights organisations continue to report that the democratic freedoms of speech, religion and press are still sadly lacking. Last month, 22-year-old Nguyen Van Hoa was sentenced to seven years in prison for blogging about an intentional toxic spill along 120 miles of coastline, which destroyed marine wildlife and damaged the health of its inhabitants. He joins Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, who was also jailed in June for highlighting the same toxic spill.  This crackdown on environmental activism using national security provisions in the Penal Code of Vietnam is deeply alarming. Sadly, although it is commendable that Vietnam has one of the highest levels of internet usage in East Asia, all media is now owned by the state, and civil and political rights are still deteriorating. In order for Vietnam to remain an important PSA and FDA partner of the European Union, I urge its government today to work to uphold the basic freedoms of its people and to release those imprisoned only for expressing their opinion.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - Madam President! Almost exactly two years ago, on December 16, human rights lawyer Nguyen Van Dai was arrested on his way to a meeting with EU representatives participating in the annual human rights dialogue with Vietnam. And like many other prisoners, he is still waiting for a trial. In today's resolution we are calling for the release of blogger and environmental activist Nguyen Van Hoa. He was sentenced to seven years in prison for anti-state propaganda. His only fault: He has called for a protest against one of the greatest environmental disasters in Vietnam. In April 2016, a Taiwanese steel mill dumped toxic dioxins into the sea. As a result, millions of dead fish were washed ashore along the coast. The disaster destroyed the livelihoods of local fishermen and their families. Vietnam must immediately end the ongoing repression against journalists and political activists and unconditionally release all political prisoners. This also includes blogger Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh. She was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment for propaganda against the state, and it was only confirmed last week, on November 30th.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, in Vietnam, like all over the world, human rights defenders are facing increasing pressure for their brave stand. In fact, our human rights are globally facing increasing pressure from nationalists, fascists and political actors not interested in democracy and freedom. We can act as politicians and we shall. But the ones making human rights come alive are civil society: the human rights defenders on the ground; the ones facing reality. By simply doing their work human rights defenders, journalists, bloggers, writers and activists are being imprisoned and attacked. More than one hundred Vietnamese people are currently behind bars for their political or religious beliefs. We call on the Vietnamese authorities to release them. The human rights defenders of the world need the EU to take a clear stand for them, for their work, and demand that regimes, like the one in Vietnam, stop harassing those who fight for justice.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: author. – Madam President, I will not repeat what the other co-authors have already said. I think the description was precise and I completely share it.  I would rather say what we now expect: Vietnam is an important partner of the European Union. We want Vietnam to maintain that position and we want to develop this relationship, but this is subject to Vietnam’s compliance with its international obligations, to reforming its legal order in a way that is compatible with its obligations ,and also to its release of the political prisoners that are detained. I must say that I was quite shocked by what we have all received from the Vietnamese permanent mission. There is clearly a lack of understanding, which is what the European Parliament is going to say today and vote on. I am sure that it will send a strong, clear political message. The only possible response, while still aiming to develop our relations, is that there will be a release and that there will be changes in the political attitudes and the legal order of Vietnam. That is the only possible reply that we will accept.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. - Madam President, I think we need to repeat exactly what happened in Vietnam, because it is unprecedented. At the end of November, a well-known Vietnamese blogger and influencer was sentenced to seven years in prison for disseminating information about the 2016 environmental disaster. Ladies and gentlemen, this man was convicted of abusing democratic freedoms to undermine state interests propaganda against the state. How typical of communist regimes! The whole process was accompanied by a number of circumstances that did not correspond to the rule of law and fundamental human rights. The blogger was detained without an official order. The trial was not public, he did not have the possibility of a lawyer and was subsequently wrongly convicted. Ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased that the whole case was accompanied by the mobilization of the population on social networks and even demonstrations in the streets. However, we, as the European Parliament and European politicians, must also intervene from our position. At present, freedom of the media, freedom of the press, speech and, in some places, even censorship can be severely restricted in Vietnam. Nguyen Van Ho's conviction shows that the government is exercising its political control, which is completely contrary to justice and the denial of human rights. That is why I think it is necessary to address this call to the Vietnamese Government.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group.- Madam President, Commissioner, I have spent the first part of my life in a totalitarian regime that tells people what to think, that gives the regime's policy above the law, above the rule of law and that restricts freedom of conscience, freedom of expression.That is why I feel very much with the people of Vietnam, who cannot enjoy this freedom, democracy and the rule of law.I am pleased that, in the case of Nguyen Van Hoy, the European Parliament will work today to ensure that this journalist, blogger and activist is released as far as possible, and with him all the other political prisoners, prisoners of conscience that Vietnam, although a major partner of the European Union,oppresses.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, in this House I have always underscored the importance of strong relations with Vietnam, a developing country that is slowly but steadily making progress in a number of areas and has shown itself a partner for the EU in the region.  Yet, while being a supporter of strengthened relations, I am seriously concerned over the deterioration of civil and political rights that we are currently witnessing. The case of Nguyen Van Hoa, who was sentenced to seven years in prison simply for informing his fellow citizens about the impact of an environmental disaster afflicting thousands of people, is deeply worrying. As is the case of many others who are detained under Article 88 of the Penal Code, which seems to be increasingly used as an instrument to silence those who stand up for human rights.  I urge the Vietnamese authorities to take seriously the pressing calls made by this House today and to review the use of security provisions to crackdown on dissidents, to release those who have been detained on that basis and to give unfettered access to the UN special rapporteurs on freedom of expression and human rights.  Whilst we should continue to support Vietnam, I really want to underline it is important that they recognise real steps have to be made in protecting human rights if we are to continue. This will go much further to ensuring security and stability in that country than oppression ever will.

name: Marek JUREK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Madam President!Vietnam is a communist country and this has its consequences.Communism is a political tyranny, but it is also a revolutionary mobilization of the masses, which in its caricatured form during periods of already established despotism means forcing people to constantly manifest support, and it is finally a utopia which again in its caricatured realization forbids telling the most elementary truths.Nguyen Van Hoa fell victim to what we saw in Belarus over thirty years ago: people must not be warned even about natural disasters or about ecological failures that threaten people.We cannot accept this power of lies.If Vietnam wants to be treated as a country cooperating with Europe, it must step by step move away from these practices, and therefore we must definitely demand the release of Nguyen Van Ho.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam president. The European Union has recently concluded negotiations for a free trade and investment agreement with Vietnam. An agreement that obviates the needs of the people without even having studied the impact it will have on human rights, already very deteriorated in that country. An agreement that, like CETA, further favors the privileged transnationals by creating arbitration tribunals; an agreement that does not have effective clauses on human rights; an agreement that only favors the interests of always, especially promoting mining and the looting of natural resources. With this agreement we will have many more cases such as that of Mr. Van Hoa that we are dealing with today and who, let us remember, has been retaliated for his peaceful resistance to the systematic violations of a company that operated under the ASEAN agreement. We are tired of the European Union filling its mouth talking about human rights and then closing its eyes, turning its back on its own principles, in the face of human rights violations, always prioritizing the commercial interest. We will never tire of demanding political coherence.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the Vietnamese government muzzles and jails political opponents, what a wonder. Vietnamese justice uses a rhetoric that furiously recalls the great Moscow trials. This regime only applies the brutal and liberticidal methods of a country where the Communist Party is the only one authorized: method of a State which has engraved in stone in its Constitution its unwavering attachment to Ho Chi Minh and to Marxism. Leninism, the ideology responsible for tens of millions of deaths; method of a state that does not hesitate to indoctrinate and recruit its youth to prevent any dissent. Last Monday the eleventh National Communist Youth Congress opened in Hanoi, during which the party's secretary general recalled that it was necessary to educate young people and arouse in them - I quote - ideology revolutionary and firm confidence in socialism, and that the awareness, study and application of Marxism-Leninism should be accelerated. One would imagine oneself in the heyday of Soviet Bolshevism. Dear colleagues, you deplore the fate of this young Vietnamese sentenced to seven years in prison for having "disseminated reactionary propaganda against the party and against politics", to use the terms of Vietnamese Pravda. But as usual, you just protest. How can we seriously hear from you? Almost nobody here opposed the Commission when it announced the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the European Union and Vietnam. In this case, you do not mind that the Union deals with the Vietnamese government to the detriment of our workers, the environment and public health. To satisfy your unbridled free trade, you suddenly pay less attention to human rights, which you invoke all the time. In this hemicycle, I have the impression that we cultivate indignation with variable geometry.To conclude, dear colleagues, if the European Union and certain Member States want to appear credible, let them first apply to themselves the lessons that they so willingly give to others, because, in our latitudes too, the systempolitico-media attempts to silence the opposition on the very fallacious pretext of fighting against racism, homophobia and so-called “hate” speech.This is a soft form of dictatorship, a dictatorship of thought, which you should not boast about and finally give up in the name of the freedom which, for us, is so essential.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, the human rights situation in Vietnam has not improved but worsened, as the case of Nguyen Van Hoa shows repeatedly. A 22-year-old blogger and videographer, who wanted to unravel the environmental disaster in Ha Tinh Province to the public, he was sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment for having disseminated online information. Also recently a Vietnamese court upheld the 10-year sentence on another blogger, Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, after she issued critical posts on environmental degradation and deaths in police custody.  As the number of detentions, arrests and convictions of Vietnamese citizens relating to expression of their opinions is rising, this situation and the restrictive approach of the authorities cannot be tolerated any more. I urge the Vietnamese Government to release all political prisoners and detainees immediately. I call on Vietnam to end the repression of freedom. There can be no closer ties between the European Union and Vietnam without respect for all these fundamental rights.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, as Ms Sánchez Caldentey reminded us, Vietnam and the EU have signed a free trade agreement. Unlike Ms Sánchez, I actually think the substance of this agreement is a good agreement – a good agreement for both the European Union and for Vietnam. But I would remind the Vietnamese that this Parliament will not judge the free trade agreement on the substance of the free trade agreement alone, but also on the political situation in the country. We will take into account the human rights situation in the country, and we will take into account the labour and environmental standards in the country when we vote on this in this Parliament. Vietnam’s current approach to freedom of expression is unacceptable; it is intolerable. They rank 175th of 180 countries in the Freedom of Expression Index. As we have heard from many speakers, they persecute bloggers who are sometimes only exposing environmental damage and environmental issues. Vietnam has to understand that if it wants to open up to the West – and we welcome it opening up to the West – it also has to open up to internal criticism. Criticism is not always opposition, it is constructive if handled properly.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Over the years, Vietnam has emerged as a full partner of the European Union and this is also confirmed in a free trade agreement. Well, the term "free" is a word that is foreign to Vietnam. The communist rulers do not tolerate freedom of the media, of assembly or of opinion. Human rights activists, journalists and bloggers face daily intimidation, violence and incarceration. That is why today we express our support for the growing number of brave citizens who have nevertheless dared to speak out against the politburo. Among them blogger Nguyen Van Hoa and human rights activist Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, both sentenced to long prison terms for spreading their message. Dear Commissioner, we as the European Union cannot tolerate the imprisonment of bloggers and activists. I therefore call on you to draw the attention of the Vietnamese government to its shortcomings and to pressure it to comply with all of its human rights obligations. Free trade and a free society go hand in hand.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, blogger Nguyen Van Hoa was convicted of opposing the environmental catastrophe in his homeland because a Taiwanese company dumped toxic industrial waste into the ocean. In other words, it is a situation that has to do with the activity of the citizens who are currently fighting against an unacceptable situation in Vietnam. This unacceptable situation in Vietnam has to do with European multinationals and other multinationals investing in Vietnam, because workers there work for a piece of bread, because social rights are not respected there, because environmental rights are not respected there. . We explained this when there was a debate here, and many people supported this Vietnam-European Union free trade cooperation, a process that is destroying both small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union and the people of Vietnam. It would therefore be good for you to think about this, colleagues, when you were in favor of the European Union-Vietnam cooperation being done and signed. These are the results of European Union policy in Vietnam. So think about these.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: - Madam President, what is happening in Vietnam is worrying, where there are citizens who have been imprisoned simply for wanting to express themselves and freely and democratically defend the human rights of their compatriots.In addition, many of these imprisoned people are not that they have not had a fair trial, but that they have not been tried and there is no provision for a trial for them.Unfortunately, political and democratic abuses are taking place by the authorities of that communist and totalitarian regime in Vietnam.For this reason, the European institutions must support and also show solidarity with Nguyen Van Hoa, who has been sentenced - as has been said here - to seven years for informing citizens of the abuses of the Vietnamese communist regime.And also the European institutions, Madam President, must recriminate that Asian country, Vietnam, its repressive policy and its tyrannical policy against its citizens.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, indeed, the Vietnamese people have already suffered greatly from the war. There are still many traces around the 37th parallel. Today, these people have the right to aspire to live in peace in a democratic regime, where justice retains its independence. It is unacceptable that a political regime - in Vietnam as elsewhere, for that matter - imprison its opponents, its bloggers and all those who aspire to freedom of expression. If Vietnam wants to continue to open up to tourism, which, without doubt, is a real wealth for this endearing country, if Vietnam wants to continue to cooperate with the European Union, its government has the obligation to respect the fundamentals of the rule of law. The Nguyen Van Hoa case is today a symbol that the European Union must integrate into its future relations with Vietnam. The European Union must remain vigilant on these questions of human rights, in Vietnam as in Cambodia, which we are going to see shortly, but also as in the big Chinese neighbor.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union has repeatedly expressed to the Vietnamese authorities, including at the highest levels, its concerns over limitations to freedom of expression, both online and offline, as reflected in frequent cases of intimidation and violence against journalists and civil society activists. The EU has been constructively engaged with the Vietnamese authorities on a revision of the penal code and its related laws, in order to ensure alignment with international standards by providing input to the National Assembly, by offering exchange of best practices, and by promoting joint actions with like-minded countries. Political and civil rights, as well as legal and judicial reform, are regularly raised at the Human Rights Dialogue with Vietnam.  During the last session, which took place on 1 December 2017 in Hanoi, the EU reiterated its request for all Vietnamese citizens detained for peacefully exercising their freedom of expression to be released. In this context, the EU also referred to a number of individual cases. Furthermore, the EU stressed that the negative trend in freedom of expression needs to be reversed, especially at a time when Vietnam and the EU are committed to working towards a closer relationship. The case of Mr Nguyen Van Hoa is a clear example of the deterioration in civil and political rights in Vietnam in recent months. The extensive application of national security provisions in Vietnam’s penal code has resulted in a steep rise in the arrest, detention and sentencing of Vietnamese citizens who peacefully express their opinions. Compared to 20 years ago, reform and modernisation have allowed Vietnam to make continuous progress in economic and social rights, steadily reaching out to international processes. The EU and Vietnam are partners in moving from limited regional integration to meeting wider international standards. Against this background, the EU is striving to reiterate, on every occasion, the concept that citizens’ opinions, expressed peacefully, enrich countries and are a pillar of sustainability and prosperity. The EU stands ready to work together with Vietnam to achieve a more inclusive society.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 December 2017.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Cambodia (banning the opposition) (2017/3002 (RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, last month, democracy and the rule of law in Cambodia received a damaging blow. Basing its decision on vague accusations and legal provisions, Cambodia’s highest court dissolved the Cambodia National Rescue Party – the main opposition party to Prime Minister Hun Sen. 118 CNRP politicians were banned from political activity for five years. Kem Sokha, President of the CNRP, is currently being held in prison on trumped-up charges, and an arrest warrant is out for the leader of the opposition, Sam Rainsy. If this situation is not reversed, then Prime Minister Hun Sen will be effectively uncontested at next year’s general elections, giving him unfettered power. Removing opponents is the text book move of a typical tyrant. The people of Cambodia, after the genocidal Khmer Rouge regime last century deserve democracy; they deserve better. They deserve an independent and impartial judiciary. Credible and transparent elections are vital to the health of the nation and the legitimacy of its government. This is one of the basic tenets that the EU member states hold dear and yet, Cambodia is a country that continues to enjoy tariff preferences to the EU market as part of the preferential ‘everything but arms’ scheme.  EU member states now have a key role to play to urge the Cambodian government to protect democracy and pluralism, as enshrined in their constitution. Cambodia’s obligations under the Convention should be immediately reviewed and all possible pressure should be put on the government to drop charges against the leaders of the opposition and to re-establish the CNRP party.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - Madam President! On November 16, at the request of the government, the Supreme Court in Cambodia dissolved the only parliamentary opposition party. The 118 elected MPs are banned from political activity for five years. The mandates of the CNRP are split between the ruling party and unelected members of other small parties at national and local levels. This is really a fatal blow to democracy in Cambodia. Prime Minister Hun Sen is doing everything possible to guarantee his re-election. The 2018 national election cannot be free and fair without a legitimate opposition and an independent electoral commission. But the EU must not give legitimacy through support for unfree and unfair elections. Critical NGOs and the media are threatened or even banned completely. Human rights activists must fear for their freedom or even their lives. Just a few days ago, Tep Vanny's politically motivated prison sentence was confirmed. Freedom of expression really looks different. The suspension of support for the national electoral commission by the EU is a first logical consequence. Prime Minister Hun Sen and his government must use targeted sanctions to send a clear signal that their approach is not acceptable to the EU.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Madam President, this is the fifth emergency resolution on Cambodia that we have been considering since 2014. The country is steadily moving further away from the rule of law. Independent media, NGOs and members of the opposition face escalating repression. All this does not bode well for the next elections. What is the point of these elections, when the main opposition party has just been dissolved and its main leaders are either in prison or in exile. On the social side, it is not much better since land grabbing remains a major phenomenon against a background of corruption benefiting a number of European multinationals and causing hundreds of thousands of refugees. So what to do? Election assistance has been suspended, the Everything But Arms deal can be used, but is it possible without penalizing textile workers? We can also support the NGO proposal for a new Paris Agreement stakeholders conference. One thing is certain: everything must be done to help Cambodia and Cambodians to return to the path of democracy, if possible.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: author. - Madam President, indeed, this is the fifth resolution on Cambodia, the second in two months, but it was necessary. Why? Because since the last resolution in October, we have visited Cambodia, several colleagues from the ASEAN delegation, including President Werner Langen and myself, and we have made the Cambodian authorities aware of the importance of not dissolving the main opposition party - because it is a gesture that obviously kills the democratization of this country - and they did not listen to us. Since then, the main opposition party, the CNPR, has been dissolved. Seven of the 55 deputies elected to the National Assembly live in the country. The majority of them, the other 48, had to leave the country because they are threatened. This is obviously not tolerable and this resolution must go further. In view of the limited impact of the many previous resolutions, I particularly welcome paragraph 12, which seems important to me, because it recommends the freezing of the assets of the dignitaries of the regime - guilty of this party dissolution - abroad and in Europe, and imposes visa restrictions. I also welcome the decision of the Commission and of the High Representative to cut the subsidies relating to democratization, because there is no democratization and therefore these European subsidies now appear to be a waste of money.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, after numerous European Union statements and five urgency resolutions on this legislation alone, I believe we should have learned the lesson. Words alone with Cambodia’s Government do not, and will not, work. We must resort to action. I certainly welcome the European Union’s decision to suspend all electoral assistance, but that is not sufficient. I therefore join others, my colleagues, in calling on the Commission to withdraw Cambodia’s participation in the ‘everything but arms’ scheme.  Lastly, the European External Action Service should, with no delay, draw up a list of those accountable for repression and impose travel bans and asset freezes on them. Without all this, the democratic opposition and civil society in Cambodia are doomed and we take responsibility for that situation.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: author. – Madam President, the European Parliament adopted an urgency resolution on Cambodia in September this year. However, the human rights situation is further deteriorating. There is an increasing number of political opposition members and human rights activists being arrested. Therefore, the European Parliament is again discussing the situation in Cambodia, notably the banning of the opposition.  The dissolution of the Cambodia National Rescue Party and the worsening climate for opposition politicians raises serious concerns, as well as the strong influence of China in the political life of Cambodia, which is playing an important role in political decisions in that country.  We welcome the EU decision to withdraw all electoral assistance until Cambodia engages in reforms, in line with international electoral standards, in order to advance democracy and protect civil society space. It is important to underline that respect for fundamental human rights is a prerequisite for Cambodia to continue to benefit from the EU’s preferential Everything But Arms (EBA) scheme. If Cambodia is acting in violation of its obligations under the EBA regulation, the tariff preferences it currently enjoys must be temporarily withdrawn.  We urge the Cambodian Government to reverse the decision to dissolve the opposition party, restore the elected members of the parliament and commune council to their position, and to allow the full participation of opposition parties in public life. In the event of a failure to guarantee political and social rights in the country, further steps in the form of sanctions might be taken by the European Union, such as an introduction of a list of individuals responsible for the dissolution of the opposition and other serious human rights violations in Cambodia, with a view to imposing possible visa restrictions and asset freezes on them.  Finally, I call on High Representative Ms Mogherini and the EU Special Representative for Human Rights to use all means available to protect the fundamental rights of the Cambodian people to elect and be elected, and to guarantee pluralism and democratic principles strictly in line with Cambodia’s Constitution.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, the Supreme Court of Cambodia has just made this country a one-party state. This decision, unsurprisingly, confirms that justice is in the hands of Prime Minister Hun Sen. This is the last step in dismantling all political opposition to the regime. The crackdown is not new, it has resulted in the arrest of Kem Sokha on charges of conspiring with the United States. Since his arrest in violation of his parliamentary immunity, the government has launched a propaganda campaign accusing the Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) of being at the center of an anti-government conspiracy. The opposition is not the only victim: the media and human rights activists are too. How in such a climate of violation of human rights and the rule of law can we hope for the organization of a free electoral process in July 2018? I believe that the European Union must respond firmly to this authoritarian drift by exerting pressure not only on the Cambodian government, but also on its Chinese neighbor, which does not hesitate to encourage this attitude.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group.- Madam President!We have often dealt with developments in Cambodia in this context, and there have been moments that were better.One could sometimes hope that the Hun-Sen regime would be ready to submit to democratic rules.The people of Cambodia want change.They deserve a better life because they did great things after the civilizational catastrophe of the years under the Khmer Rouge.Hun Sen is currently wrecking everything.All who fight for a free, social and just Cambodia are being fought with unbelievable brutality.The time has come for Europe to show the corrupt dictator the red card and sanction the regime by withdrawing aid - technically and financially - and with travel restrictions for those who willfully destroy democracy in this much-plagued country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, Cambodia is a rich country with mines, timber, oil. Unfortunately, the people of Cambodia do not reap the benefits of exploiting their country's natural resources. We have been reporting these events and human rights violations in Cambodia since 26 November 2015. It is well known what is happening in Cambodia. It is well known that there the regime is violating human rights, there is a lack of pluralism, there is persecution of the opposition, which has been peaking lately, and there is action of the armed forces and security forces that act uncontrollably and suppress demonstrations and strikes. We have denounced all this and it was known, nevertheless there was and continues to be European Union development assistance in Cambodia and the preferential agreement continues to work. Economic measures must therefore be taken against the authoritarian regime in Cambodia, so that it can realize that it must stop violating human rights.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, we have addressed human rights violations in Cambodia repeatedly and the dissolving of the National Rescue Party, as well as the barring of 118 of its politicians from political activity for five years, is another reason for deep concern. There is now effectively no alternative to the government, and when politicians are silenced, despite their immunity, the situation of civil society and human rights defenders is even worse. The EU should attach consequences to these serious developments. Respect for fundamental human rights is a prerequisite to continuing to grant the benefits from the EU’s preferential ‘Everything But Arms’ trade scheme, and EUR 410 million is foreseen to go to Cambodia over the next couple of years. We call for an immediate review of Cambodia’s obligations and for the withdrawal of trade preferences and financial support in response to the recent events, as well as the structural human rights violations. Individual sanctions, including asset freezing and visa bans, should also be part of the consideration of which consequences are needed and appropriate.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, dear colleagues, in one year, barely five votes on Cambodia! We didn’t vote so much for the Christians of the East, we didn’t vote as much for the Africans tortured on the Great Lakes. That Prime Minister Hun Sen is not a Democrat, of course. That, I'm sure. We still have to agree on what remains of democracy here. For us, there are, in fact, good dictators and bad dictators and, among us, a somewhat weak dictatorship. Take the example of a man against whom we have not voted since 2014: Paul Kagame, the author of the unrest and mass murders which bloodied the Great Lakes region, labeled a good dictator. By comparison, do Hun Sen and the small state of Cambodia deserve such relentlessness? Human rights are not for political use, to lock us into logics of power and influence, in the service, moreover, of interests other than those of Europe. Let us help Cambodia by starting from realities to improve them, without double standards.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, as the banning of the opposition clearly shows, the Prime Minister and his ruling party are only willing to hold free elections if they are sure that they will win and they do not shy away from deploying anti—democratic practices to secure their rule. Sadly, ordering the closure of the main opposition party follows a wider pattern in this regard. Independent media outlets have already been reduced to silence and critical NGOs have been under attack. The government also expressed its intention to prosecute people who criticise it on social media. Unfortunately, these incidents are taking place in the context of a shift away from the West, and the US Administration’s diminished interest in human rights. Even so, the EU is still the biggest grant donor in Cambodia. China has recently increased its aid and investment in the country without human rights strings attached. To reverse this trend, the EU should use all its means to put pressure on the Cambodian Government to restore the democratic principles from its Constitution.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to join my predecessors in criticizing the Cambodian regime.On the basis of such vague resolutions, it is not possible for the Supreme Court to dissolve the main opposition party and ban several dozen Cambodian politicians from operating.I think it is important that we also say enough to the Cambodian state, if it does not recognize and respond to our resolution, to the resolution of one of the institutions of the European Union that has so far strongly supported Cambodia.I welcome the European Commission's decision to suspend payments, but the question of the dissolution of the main opposition party also has an impact on the assessment of the validity of next year's elections.I think we should give a clear signal that we will not recognize the validity of these elections.As for other sanctions, I think we should also proceed with visa restrictions, which should only be granted in exceptional cases.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, indeed, as the resolution we are debating clearly indicates, today we have to worry about the lack of political plurality in Cambodia. The ruling party reigns supreme and even allows itself to dissolve the main opposition party, which nevertheless obtained significant results in the local elections. The resolution re-emphasizes arbitrary arrests and false imprisonment. Under these conditions, the European Union must continue its action to try to make itself heard and to take measures aimed at hitting the government at the portfolio, as our colleague Marc Tarabella has just explained very well. In addition, the clothing sector, which is one of the main economic sectors with outlets in the European Union, must also be the subject of special attention so that we do not experience a new Rana Plaza that mourned Bangladesh. The next elections in June 2018 will have to be transparent and in accordance with international criteria, otherwise the European Union will have to harden its relations with this regime, but keep in mind that it must support the Cambodian people.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Madam President, the information that comes from Cambodia is more than alarming. The parliament has recently approved repressive amendments and the Minister of the Interior has got such strong power to suspend the main opposition political party, and its president has been arrested. The current conditions totally alter competition amongst parties and if the situation stays the same the future election will be just a comedy.  I have had the privilege to be a short-term electoral observer more than once and in several countries. I can largely say that respecting the voting procedure is not enough to guarantee a fair election. The integrity of the voting system needs to be complemented by a democratic long-term environment. Suppressing political parties, conferring powers on a government and drawing up tailored electoral laws, changing the rules of the game in the run-up to the elections, are all ways to corrupt the system and prevent a democratic election.  We should condemn the improper actions of the Cambodian Government and the serious violation of human rights, and call on the European Union to suspend commercial benefits until democracy is restored.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: - Madam President! Six weeks ago I had the opportunity to visit Cambodia as part of a trip by the ASEAN delegation. It's really depressing. Cambodia is a beautiful country that has unfortunately been invaded by an ideology in its history, where in the past a quarter of the population was murdered by its own government. This country has now earned democracy. It didn't deserve the cheek that is currently taking place there. Incidentally, the cheek towards our delegation. I have never seen anything like this on my delegation trips, even in totalitarian states. I think what happened there is also absolutely against the will of the people and, above all, absolutely against the will of the young people who finally want something different after three decades of the Hun Sen government. We should also consider one thing: We have paid for a new system for elections in this country, which makes election fraud de facto impossible. The answer to our investment now is that the country will become a dictatorship and elections will only be farce. I think that too should be a lesson to us: in this case, we have spent our money completely unreasonably.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the European Union remains deeply concerned about the continuing deterioration of the political situation in Cambodia and the escalating repression of the opposition and civil society. Cambodia is heading towards increasing authoritarianism. In recent months, the Cambodian Government has taken action to stifle political opposition, to suffocate democracy. We have underlined that the decision of the Cambodian Government on 16 November to dissolve the main opposition party, the Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP), is a significant step away from the path of pluralism and democracy enshrined in Cambodia’s Constitution and supported for more than two decades by Cambodia’s international partners, including the European Union. We reiterate that an electoral process from which the main opposition party has been arbitrarily excluded is not legitimate. The CNRP won one over 43% of the vote at the 2016 commune elections and 44.5% in the 2013 legislative elections. Its dissolution disenfranchises is those voters.  The 1991 Paris Accords created binding legal obligations upon the parties, including the duty of the Cambodian Government to maintain liberal multi—party democracy, as well as to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms. These commitments are enshrined in the Cambodian Constitution. The European Union and its Member States have put, and continue to put, huge efforts and very significant resources into supporting the development of Cambodia. It is therefore very worrying to see over the last months a significant narrowing of the democratic space in the country.  On 20 November, High Representative Mogherini met with the Cambodian Foreign Minister, Prak Sokhonn, on the margins of the ASEM Ministerial Meeting in Myanmar. She insisted on the expectation that the continued detention of the opposition leader, Kem Sokha, and the dissolution of the CNRP would be swiftly reversed. The High Representative also recalled that the EU’s development cooperation and trade preferences were reliant on Cambodia’s respect for fundamental human rights. We are currently assessing the situation in terms of development cooperation assistance. In this regard, the EU has decided to suspend its support to the national election committee. The EU will continue to reaffirm its commitment to protect and to promote the universality of human rights whenever they are violated or questioned, whether inside or outside its borders.  The principle of democratic inclusion and dialogue is key to lasting peace and stability. We encourage the Cambodian Government to find a way out of this impasse, through a structured dialogue with the opposition. We will also continue to raise with the government the need to apply the law evenly and fairly to all, and the need to ensure that freedom of association, expression and due process are fully respected.  Respect for fundamental human and labour rights is also part of our trade policy and underpins the legal basis of our trade preferences. Our development cooperation with Cambodia is long term and any consideration regarding a suspension of cooperation would have to be carefully evaluated in terms of its impact. Suspension of aid could be detrimental to the population. On the temporary withdrawal of Cambodia from the Everything But Arms (EBA) arrangement, the Commission, in cooperation with the EEAS, is monitoring the situation in Cambodia to check whether the conditions for taking measures, under Article 19 of the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP) regulations, are fulfilled.  The European Union remains ready to support the government of Cambodia in strengthening Cambodia’s developing democratic system.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 December 2017.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on El Salvador (prosecution of women for abortion) (2017/3003 (RSP)).

name: Marek JUREK
text: author. - Madam President! El Salvador is a free, democratic country that wants to defend life. Anyway, this status of El Salvador as a free, democratic state is confirmed by the rankings of The Economist and Freedom House. This state wants to defend life and is therefore under attack. It is time for this incitement against the right to life to end in this Parliament. And when one day in Europe and this Parliament ends, then the conditions will really be created for talking about practical, technical ways to protect life, because if the right to life is confirmed, then of course it is possible to discuss how to do it. Ireland, Poland, Malta and El Salvador do it in different ways. And precisely because this law needs to be strengthened, we in Poland want to change and improve it, make Poland an even safer country for those who protect lives. As for El Salvador, it is time we stopped attacking countries whose only fault is defending human rights.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: author. – Madam President, in September I visited Ilopango prison in El Salvador during a Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly (EuroLat) visit to that country. I was shocked by what I found. Women had been imprisoned, their lives stolen, simply because of unwanted pregnancies, in some cases because they had suffered miscarriage or been raped. Gender-based violence is a major problem in El Salvador, where a woman is sexually assaulted every three hours and rape and incest often result in unwanted pregnancies. Since 1998, abortion has been criminalised in all circumstances, even when continuing the pregnancy is life-threatening or when the foetus is non-viable. Between 2011 and 2015, 14 women died of complications related to abortion.  We know that the Government in El Salvador is working to improve this situation and we acknowledge the work of European diplomats supporting women who have been unjustly jailed. We hope that this resolution will draw attention to the plight of women like Teodora del Carmen Vásquez and Evelyn Beatriz Hernández Cruz, who should be granted a pardon while we wait for changes to the law.  (Applause)

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. - Madam president. We are here to demand the freedom of Teodora del Carmen Vásquez, Evelyn Beatriz Hernández and all the women imprisoned in El Salvador for aborting or suffering miscarriages. Also to demand the total decriminalization of abortion in this country, but also in other parts of the world where abortion is prohibited or only allowed in some circumstances. The denial of sexual and reproductive health as well as the safe and legal interruption of pregnancy constitute a form of violence against women, as well as a serious violation of their rights and dignity. The much talked about gender equality cannot be achieved without guaranteeing the free decision of women about their bodies. We demand that the European Union and its member states be and ensure the recognition of the right to access voluntary family planning and safe and legal abortion for all women, whether in El Salvador, in Europe, or in any other country of the world.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. - Madam President, in El Salvador abortion is prohibited in all cases. In all. Including rape, of course. But it was also punished as in Europe we punish murders, with sentences of up to thirty years in prison. Because it is considered aggravated homicide, even miscarriage. Evelyn Hernández is a young Salvadoran who was raped. She claims that her son was stillborn. And yet she is sentenced to thirty years in prison. And so are seventeen other women in Salvadoran prisons, including Teodora del Carmen Vásquez, whose sentence has just been confirmed by the judge. We are facing a huge injustice and it is a punishment against the women of one of the countries with the most violence in the entire region. It is a punishment against the most vulnerable. It is a repeated, insistent punishment against the victims themselves. And it is a punishment for the whole of the country, because what it does is block its progress, its development and its evolution. And we are not just talking about a question of freedom. The price of the prohibition and extreme criminalization of abortion is neither more nor less than the life and health of women. I deeply regret that in this House there is not a will and a consensus on what the United Nations high commissioner has asked: decriminalization of abortion in all circumstances and the possibility of abortion in some cases, at least, as in El Salvador.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, I would like to say to the Salvadorian authorities: who are you to decide on women’s lives or women’s bodies? How can a miscarriage be criminalised? We, as parliamentarians, with our democratic values and respect for human rights, take a stand against your violations. States and churches do not have the right to violate our human dignity. My body is my body and it is my decision whether to have an abortion or not. Every woman across the world is entitled to make her choice for herself. We stand up for women who have been targeted under these laws. I call on the Salvadorian authorities: release the women from prison, abolish the laws that require hospitals to report women seeking health care to the police. Our resolution shows that we are taking action against all forms of violations of women’s human rights. As a strong feministic politician, I stand in international solidarity with all women and the right to decide over our bodies and lives. Today we got the news about Teodora Vásquez. She has had her appeal rejected so her sentence to 30 years in prison stands. This is disgusting in El Salvador. And I want to say to Mr Jurek: do you find this is justice, 30 years of prison because of this? How can you look on this as a criminal action? Shame on you! (Applause) (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Bernd Lucke)

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author. - Madam President! Today we are talking about El Salvador, a small Central American country where relatively recently, in 1998, a total ban on abortion was introduced into law. It means that even a woman who is raped or whose pregnancy is life-threatening cannot terminate her pregnancy. It is a very cruel law that treats women objectively and contemptuously, and which in El Salvador is further interpreted in a way that ignores the principles of justice, the presumption of innocence and scientific knowledge. Well, women who experience miscarriage or pregnancy necrosis are accused of abortion or murder of a child and are sentenced to many years in prison. Therefore, pregnancy for a woman in El Salvador is a drama, especially when she is unmarried and is still a child herself. Pregnant girls commit suicide in fear of the consequences. In El Salvador, suicide causes more than half of the deaths in pregnant women between the ages of 10 and 19. Many women die as a result of complications of pregnancy. Any abnormal pregnancy immediately raises suspicions and accusations of attempted abortion or fetal death, so women with difficult pregnancies simply avoid doctors. I appeal to the Salvadoran authorities to stop the inhumane treatment of women, to introduce a law providing for exceptions to the prohibition of abortion and to release from prison women incarcerated there for acts which, in the light of international standards of law and medical knowledge, cannot be treated as crimes. Madam President! I would like to add one more sentence in response to what Mr. Marek Jurek said. I would like to say that I hope that Polish law will never come close to the law that is currently in force in El Salvador. And I would like to point out that attempts to introduce such a law brought 100,000 women to the streets as part of the "black march" and thousands of women around the world who showed solidarity with Polish women. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by lifting the blue cards (Rule 162 (8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam, you have just heard that a child is part of a woman's body.After all, in the party's state program, you write that the right to life should be protected just like in Poland.These are the judgments of the Polish Constitutional Tribunal.Is all this really just for voters?Why don't you react when you hear your incitement against the right to life?

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr.I would like to point out that Polish law contains three exceptions to the prohibition of abortion.These are the exceptions that we are fighting for at the moment to be in El Salvador that make it possible to construct a law that is conservative and protects life, but also that recognizes that a woman is a living being and a citizen.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Teodora del Carmen Vásquez has been in prison for ten years and will serve a sentence of thirty years in jail. What crime did she commit? She gave birth to a dead baby. Teodora shares a cell with 70 other women in Ilopango prison. This resolution fortunately takes a strong political position on the case of Teodora and other women subject to the same inhumanity, the same cruelty, the case of the group known as “the seventeen” who are also held in the same prison and also serving long prison sentences several decades in jail. I believe that the indignation and pressure of the European Union towards the authorities in El Salvador can be important in trying to reverse the situation of these women. I would like to extend a greeting to the Salvadoran people and praise the vitality of civil society in this country, which, after many years, has managed to stir consciences and put a discussion on the decriminalization of abortion on the agenda. It is largely due to the courageous work of these civil society organizations that a legislative proposal is now being considered in the National Assembly to make the abortion law more decent and more humane. From here, I launch the idea and the hope that it will be possible for Salvadoran legislators to move resolutely on this path to put an end to this so cruel and so deeply inhuman spectacle.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, conservative forces in El Salvador consider women and girls as incubators in fact, to the extent that female human beings end up in jail for two to eight years for miscarriages and for up to 50 years for abortions. To a healthy mind this sounds like a bizarre nightmare but in fact this is the everyday reality for women and girls in El Salvador in the year 2017.  For those in this House who think this should not be our business as it is in fact saving lives, I would like to ask you: how many more women and girls should suffer and die before you will understand that this is cynical, killing human beings, and in fact defending murder. I don’t know about you but I will certainly not leave those women and girls alone.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Teodora and Evelyn are two women who have faced unbearable hardships in their lives. Not only have they suffered miscarriages, now they are being charged for murder and have been sentenced to prison for years and years. To the Salvadorian authorities: release Teodora, Evelyn and all the other women who are in prison for a miscarriage. The current law in El Salvador is misogyny poured into law. It is an outcome of an ideology and a quest for absolute patriarchal power over female bodies. No matter where a woman is born, her body belongs to her and not to the state or to men who believe they know what to do with it. Women have a right to life too. My body, my rights.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Madam president.Teodora del Carmen is thirty-four years old and has been in prison for more than ten years.She was imprisoned for ten years for having lost her daughter in a premature birth, and the Salvadoran authorities confirmed yesterday the thirty-year sentence.Women in El Salvador are criminalized.It's not just Teodora.There are more than thirty cases of women who have suffered spontaneous abortions and who are in prisons deprived of their liberty.We cannot allow from Europe that in any corner of the world women are being deprived of their freedom for deciding on their lives.We have to be aware that we are talking about human rights, and the foreign policy and cooperation policy of the European Union must guarantee the sexual and reproductive health rights of all women in the world.Because their fight is our fight.Our body is freedom.We will continue working from Europe for all women in the rest of the world.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, when my colleague Mr Jurek finished his speech, I felt that he was speaking on a completely different point.Not a word about solidarity with women, about understanding that miscarriage or stillbirth is a different fact than miscarriage.Nor am I a supporter of, say, exaggerated abortion opportunities for women, but on the other hand I must perceive circumstances that are perhaps understandable and that are being discussed here.That is why I would like to express my solidarity with those women from El Salvador who are affected by this legislation, and I think that all sensible colleagues in this House should condemn this legislation, and I would say dogmatists from Poland (the speaker refused to answer the question,placed by raising a blue card from Marek Jurek.)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate on abortion has always raised questions that affect our consciences, intersecting with cultural and religious issues, and consequently diversifying legislative paths in the world. But there is a red line that should never be crossed, that of the rights and dignity of women. El Salvador is among the countries with the most restrictive laws on women's rights. The case of the nineteen-year-old girl Evelyn Beatriz Hernandez Cruz, sentenced to thirty years in prison for having suffered a spontaneous abortion, also following a rape, has shaken international public opinion. In its March 2017 resolution on equality between men and women, the European Parliament stated that women must be in control of their sexual and reproductive health and related rights, and that the denial of life-saving sexual and reproductive health services, including safe abortion, amounts to a serious violation of human rights. In addition to strongly condemning any act against women's rights, the European Union is obliged to do everything in its power to ensure that all women imprisoned for having suffered a spontaneous or involuntary abortion are released.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, something unbelievable is happening in El Salvador: The law imposes a prison sentence if a fetus is stillborn or has an abortion. This is the central issue that we are discussing today and this is something that I think all sides of this room are complaining about, because it is not possible that there is no presumption of innocence and it cannot be considered that, for every fetus that is born dead or in case of premature abortion, it is the mother's responsibility to take her to prison. A glaring case is that of Evelin, who has been sentenced to thirty years in prison and charged with homicide. So I think we need to focus on these central issues, because this is a practice in El Salvador, as at least 147 women have been convicted. So you understand that at this central point there is unity, I think, of all sides here and it is something we must condemn.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Madam President, since 1998 abortion has been persecuted. Since 2000, almost more than 120 women have been prosecuted for this issue. Sentenced to between thirty and fifty years. It doesn't matter if they were raped, it doesn't matter if their life was in danger. Today my thoughts go to Teodora, ten years already in prison; for eighteen-year-old Evelyn, with more than thirty years in jail ahead. And I think it is very important that this Parliament is going to ask for your freedom today and that the necessary legislative changes are made to put an end to this situation. And I want to say that we are not far from it, because at the moment there are initiatives in the Salvadoran Congress to change the law. And that is why I believe that it is essential that the European Union give a push to these legislative changes so that we can get to change this situation. The delegation of the European Union in El Salvador is doing a good job in this regard and it is very important that, in view of what will happen next year with the elections in the country, this could be a real change that operate and that these women can get out of jail and that, once and for all, a woman is never prosecuted for having had an abortion.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, since 1998, abortion in El Salvador is criminalised under any circumstances. Any woman suspected of having had an abortion, including those who went through miscarriage, risk up to 50 years of imprisonment. Consequently, many women have been prosecuted and many others have died due to pregnancy complications. El Salvador’s anti-abortion law is causing nothing but pain and suffering to countless women and their families.  Sadly, we heard yesterday that the court decided to uphold the 30-year jail sentence for Carmen Vásquez. This is undoubtedly a step back for justice and women’s rights. Denying women and girls access to sexual and reproductive rights, including safe and legal abortion, is a violation of their rights to life and health. We urge the Parliament of El Salvador to support the bill introducing the reform of the Criminal Code in order to decriminalise abortion under certain circumstances. We also urge the government to introduce a moratorium on the enforcement of the current law.  Today’s resolution is a message to these women. You are not alone. We stand by your side in this battle.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!I would like to exercise the right of reply to this Member under Art.164 of the Regulations.I would like to point out to both the Soraya Post and to Mr Polčák that you rely all the time on data provided by Amnesty International.We are talking about an organization that in this Parliament, for example in the LIBE committee, has repeatedly declared itself to be a pro-abortion organization, an organization that treats a child not even as an organ of a woman's body, but as an appendix that can be cosmetically removed at its own will or not.Really listen to the explanations of the Salvadoran authorities and do not rely on this one-sided propaganda.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the EU is very much aware of the situation of women prosecuted for miscarriage in El Salvador. The EU does not comment on judicial decisions but observes with significant concern that on many occasions maximum criminal penalties were applied to women who had a miscarriage in El Salvador. Respect for the rule of law is one of the fundamental values upon which the EU is based. Therefore the EU is very much attached to the presumption of innocence, as well as to upholding the principles of proportionality, due process and the provision of legal aid in all judicial processes. To follow up the situation closely, the EU is in regular contact with local associations, such as citizens’ groups, which provide support to women and girls during their trials. Under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, the EU has also supported the provision of legal assistance to human rights organisations. The relative scarcity of sexual and reproductive health services in El Salvador is another important obstacle to address the issue of miscarriage. It is also a key area of progress to improve women’s lives in the country. Respect for, and the promotion of, women’s rights is at the core of the EU agenda in El Salvador and beyond. From a human rights angle, the total ban on abortion foreseen in the constitution and criminal code of El Salvador is worrying, especially when the lives of pregnant women or young girls are at risk or in cases of rape. Total bans on abortion are also a problem in several other countries in Latin America.  The EU raises this issue at the highest level in El Salvador and welcomes the efforts deployed by the Government to improve in a comprehensive manner the alarming situation of women. Among other initiatives, the EU has provided support to the flagship and successful programme ‘Ciudad Mujer’ (Women’s City), created by the Government and which has meaningfully contributed to enhancing women’s and girls’ access to sexual and reproductive health services, but also to address gender-based violence, as well as to promote women’s economic empowerment.  The EU encourages El Salvador and all other countries concerned by this important challenge to continue pursuing efforts in this direction and stands ready to help on this issue.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 December 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - The situation in El Salvador with regard to the persecution of women for miscarriages is very worrying. Since 2000 In El Salvador, at least 120 women have been prosecuted for abortion or murder in cases where the fetus died in the last months of pregnancy and all convicts have been sentenced to extremely long prison terms, even though they are not criminals by international standards. Not to mention, gender-based violence is one of El Salvador’s biggest problems. Data show that one woman is sexually abused every three hours, and rape cases often end in unwanted pregnancies. It is important to note that the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, ratified by El Salvador, defines forced pregnancy as a crime against humanity and a form of gender-based violence against women, which is a serious violation of human rights and the dignity of women and girls. Thus, the human rights situation of girls and women, including sexual and reproductive health care and rights, in El Salvador is a matter of grave concern, and I therefore strongly oppose the sentencing and imprisonment of women and girls who have given birth or have had a miscarriage and join calls for their immediate and unconditional release. .

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the dramatic consequences of the total ban on abortion in El Salvador in 1998. Such a law that treats women as an object is in itself inhumane and contrary to human rights. Additionally, in El Salvador, women who miscarry, have a stillborn child or experience complications in pregnancy are suspected and often accused of attempting to abort or even murdering a child and are sentenced to decades of hard prison. Calls for international opinion to end these inhumane practices and changes to the law can help El Salvadoran women get out of their tragic situation. At this point, it is worth noting that the ideas of a total ban on abortion appear in the public sphere also in Europe. In Poland, in autumn 2016, they were even turned into a bill, which was submitted to the Sejm and its proceedings began, and many people from the ruling party publicly supported this bill. The ruling party's support for barbaric law brought over 100,000 to the streets. Polish women, and their protest met with the solidarity of tens of thousands of women around the world, who manifested their support through public declarations published in social media. I hope that, contrary to the intentions of some of the debaters of today's debate on the resolution, Polish law will never come close to that which is currently in force in El Salvador.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is voting time.(Voting results and other details of the voting: see Minutes.)

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, I have an oral amendment in connection with some legal action that took place last night. We need to change recital C so that at the end, it reads: ‘whereas after spending the last 10 years in prison, Teodora del Carmen Vásquez’s case was reviewed by the Second Sentencing Tribunal on 13 December 2017 and her appeal was rejected.’.

name: Nicola DANTI
