text: in place of the rapporteur.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the rapporteur Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto, I ask this House to support the negotiating mandate given last week by the Internal Market Committee in order to start trilogues with the Council on this report.The text adopted by the IMCO commission on the basis of broad support has significantly improved the original proposal of the European Commission, particularly with regard to respecting the democratic legitimacy of local assemblies and national parliaments.We are convinced that the large majority obtained in the vote in committee will allow the rapporteur to start a trilogue with a strong and defined mandate.That is why I ask on behalf of the rapporteur to support the negotiating mandate.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: - I will certainly admit that Parliament has tried to somewhat correct the bad proposal from the Commission, but it is still a question of postponing national democratic decision-making by three to six months.If we allow this to continue, it will certainly go back to how the European Union is perceived.Then you have to imagine that in municipal councils, in local democratic representations, the Commission must first speak before they can continue with their decision-making.That is why I think this is worth a plenary debate and we should come back to it next time.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all my colleagues for the great support. Let us join forces today to send a clear and strong message to all Member States that they have to do more – better and faster – to protect children. Let us, together with the law enforcement authorities, civil society and the IT industry, stand up for zero tolerance against child sexual abuse and exploitation, online and offline. It is really time to go from words to action and ensure that Europe truly means safety for all kids.  (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The voting time is now closed.I would like to remind you once again that your vote will only be accepted if you withdraw your card after the vote has ended.I wish you all a safe journey home.If you won't be in Brussels next week, we wish you a rest of the contemplative Advent season and a merry Christmas.The same goes for the services, of course.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I would like to explain that I voted against the objection raised by a group of Members to the Commission regulation authorizing phosphates in frozen meat.I also spoke in the discussion, where I explained my justification.In the end, this objection in yesterday's vote did not really go through very narrowly, by three votes.I am also convinced that this was thanks to the explanation provided by the Commission here in plenary, which we, as the European People's Party, pushed for to be discussed in plenary so that we could explain our reasons.Citizens in the European Union do not have to worry, because daily phosphate consumption will certainly not increase, and the minimum amount allowed in frozen meat used, for example, to make kebabs will not increase the danger and harm.Of course, we will continue to monitor very closely and proceed with further authorization.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, I also did not support the proposed resolution in this vote, not because I lack a sense of consumer protection, but I do not think we should exaggerate.If we have had scientifically based statements from our own agencies, agencies set up by the European Union, which have been able to explain to us in a qualified way that there is really no danger that both the concentration of these substances and the amount consumed are well below levels that could cause any harm at all.health.Then I feel that we have voted a little unnecessarily, and I would advocate that, albeit perhaps in good faith and guided by goodwill, colleagues do not abuse the plenary to vote on matters that are not absolutely necessary.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Yes, there are indications that phosphates in food can harm health.The health effects of phosphates are currently being evaluated by the European Food Safety Agency and the results are expected by the end of 2018.It is therefore logical to wait for this EFSA report before deciding on additional exceptions for the use of phosphates in food.Moreover, the consumer is in danger of being left out in the cold.Phosphates can increase the weight of meat thanks to their water-binding capacity and no information is given about this via a product label.This is not at all about banning kebabs.Innovation makes alternatives to phosphates possible.In Flanders, Flanders' FOOD plays a strong role in this.This is important not only for health reasons, but also for efficient use of the scarce raw material that is phosphate.For all these reasons, the N-VA delegation has supported the objection.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I did not support this objection either, because it is important to say that phosphates are used in a number of other food products, whether they are cola drinks or in the confectionery industry. There are a number of types of phosphates, and here the Commission, I think, has quite rightly filled a gap in the law by allowing the use of phosphate in these frozen semi-finished products. If the European Food Safety Authority's study on the safety of these substances is to be carried out next year, I think that, at the moment, it was more of a concern in the case of the colleagues who are raising this objection. The limits allowed by the regulation are many times smaller than the daily allowable limits. Therefore, for these reasons too, I did not support the objection, but at the same time I want to state that I will be following the evaluation of the whole group of phosphates, as carried out by the European Food Safety Authority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I voted against the objection, because the use of phosphates in meat preparations poses various risks to the health of consumers, in particular the extension of the use of phosphates in frozen meat preparations cooked on vertical skewers, such as the well-known Turkish gourd, sold in Germany and other Western European countries, is a source of health risk for consumers. In Greece, Greek gyros and kebabs do not have phosphates, as their tenderness, stabilization and production of the final product is achieved in other purely healthy ways. In essence, the Greek round is a guaranteed traditional idiosyncratic product that needs recognition and legislative protection. Therefore, the ban on the use of phosphates in the round would, in essence, lead to a ban on the import of the Turkish round in Germany. The solution is simple: Take advantage of the Greek round that is healthy. Prohibit the import of frozen round from Turkey.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report. Trillions of pounds, euros and dollars are being siphoned off through loopholes to avoid tax, while our public services are starved of money and the world’s poorest are hit hardest. This is a global problem but the Panama Papers revealed Britain to be top of the leader board, with the greatest number of offshore companies and trusts amongst EU nations.  Sadly, though, our government has not shown leadership in Westminster to tackle tax dodging, and here in Europe, and again and again, the Conservatives have sought to water down and block action to combat tax avoidance, including failing to vote for the conclusions of Parliament’s Committee of inquiry into Money Laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion (Panama Committee).  I welcome the blacklist of tax havens and sanctions against them, more transparency, more cooperation, as well as a globally recognised definition of a tax haven. It is high time we end having one set of rules for the super-rich, and another for the rest of us.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President!I fully agree with the Commission's recommendations, all the more so because there are countless Member States in the European Union that are unfortunately cooperating with harmful practices.My strong assumption is that it is not enough to simply look around taxes, but I also think it is important for member states to ban offshore companies from intervening in public procurement.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: - Mr President, 1 trillion euros per year, that is what tax fraud and tax evasion represent.Inaction costs every European citizen 2,000 euros each year, and we are told about a united Europe, a Europe that protects.In fact, behind the bombastic speeches, we organize behind the scenes the possibility for multinationals and multimillionaires to slip through the cracks.This hypocrisy no longer deceives anyone, so hypocritical that Luxembourg has been forgotten to put on the famous blacklist, as well as the beautiful and clean countries of Liechtenstein, Switzerland, Monaco and Andorra.It is high time to really fight financial terrorism, always unpunished, in the service of an ever richer ultra-minority, to the detriment of the poorest, unfortunately always poorer.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President, I appreciate every action by the European Union in the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance and the legalization of revenue in tax havens. Such action not only damages the existing system, but is also immoral and grossly robs society of the resources that should be devoted to its development, to the development of individuals in each country. EU countries, and therefore Slovakia, lose around € 60 billion a year. However, the blacklist of non-cooperating tax havens will not help to address the huge tax evasions for which some European countries are also responsible. A colleague named them here now. If we want to be consistent in the fight against tax evasion as the EU, we must find the courage to look into our own ranks. The absence of such a decision forced me to abstain. I am also convinced that the high tax burden and tax harmonization reduce the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises in the Member States of the Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I have been very much considering voting on this report.In the end, I supported this report because the final form, in my opinion, is in line with the effort to prevent tax evasion.I really find them immoral, it is not possible to record them further to those who abuse the law or even explicitly violate the law.This also applies to the Member States of the European Union.I think that unfair tax competition between Member States violates the principles on which the European Union is based and is as bad as direct taxation at European Union level.I finally agreed that we should seek a balance between these two extremes.And I think that certain measures and mechanisms proposed by the European Commission can help to combat these leaks and punish the black passengers who are actually on the train that others are pulling.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, let me explain why I voted in favor of the report on the annual report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy.In today's world, in a situation where we increasingly have to face dangers, very close cooperation is needed, both in the security and foreign fields.It is therefore very right that the paragraph we voted on was approved in our report, which also calls for an extension of sanctions against individuals and entities in Russia, because this is necessary given the failure to implement the Minsk agreements.Of course, we must be primarily interested in a situation that is not stable and concerns our immediate neighborhood.The report responds correctly to the opacity of the current international environment, and the European Union must be more active in this area.This is a request from the citizens of the European Union, and the European Parliament is accommodating in this.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! I voted in favor of the adoption of the report on last year's and next year's tasks for the European Union's common foreign and security policy, appreciating its very thorough and innovative in many respects. The report is a good reflection of the European Union's response to the new security challenges in its environment, the changing content of the transatlantic relationship, the destabilization of our Mediterranean neighborhood and international terrorism, as well as the potential for Brexit, in the forthcoming Common Foreign and Security Policy. consequences. In the light of the circumstances and arguments set out in the report, I agree that I consider it appropriate to create European strategic autonomy to protect the EU and its Member States, eliminate overlaps, improve force mobility, implement PESCO, and increase global ownership through Common Foreign and Security Policy missions. requires additional funding in the future.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, clearly the EU needs to become a stronger and more coherent foreign policy actor, and I agree with the fact that we need more coordination between Member States in order to guarantee major security for our citizens.  However, I voted against the report for the following reason. The call to raise national defence budgets to 2% of GDP in the coming decade is going to bring unbalanced results in a number of EU countries. This will jeopardise the efforts of some Member States to improve their social policies. Just to give you an example: in Latvia the budget for 2018 foresees EUR 208 million for military expenses, yet only EUR 28 million for family allowances and children’s needs. This means that children in Latvia could get around EUR 45 more per day if the military expenses went to households. In this regard, I would suggest that the EU makes more of an effort in raising the efficiency of military spending, including optimisation of industrial sectors, and so on.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, let me explain why, in the end, I could not vote in favor of the report on human rights in the world, even though I am always very sensitive on this subject.Namely, the report approved passages calling for the expansion of sexual and reproductive rights, in other words, the promotion of abortion in the world.Nor can I agree with the repeated call for compliance with the mandatory refugee quotas, which the President of the European Council Tusk has already described as dysfunctional.Nevertheless, I think it is important for the European Parliament to systematically address the human rights situation, because we have great problems around us, even in nearby Turkey, when we look at Turkey's human rights violations and the imprisonment of its academics and journalists.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! Even in states with democratic systems, the lack of political advocacy capacity of minorities and the resulting conflicts are a constant concern. If a linguistic or ethnic-based community is confronted with the fact that the majority is constantly forcing its will, not involving it in decisions that affect the life of that country, or directly discriminating against members of the minority community, then conflict is coded into the situation. The European Union cannot change the political and social systems of all countries, but it could set an example to the world in ensuring human rights and the protection of minorities. Unfortunately, this example is not clear today, as the EU institutions are not putting pressure on the Member States because of the often incomplete policies and practices for the protection of minorities. The report emphasizes that minority communities have special needs and that the rights and full equality of these communities in all areas of economic, social, political and cultural life must be promoted. This finding should also be validated in the Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, Hong Kong’s Special Administrative Region is one of the few places in Asia where democracy is efficient and visible. It is an example of a vibrant society that is looking for ways to consolidate its democratic values. Therefore, the European Union should intensify its contacts with Hong Kong in the framework of the Structured Dialogue. We should make sure that, during the next decade, Hong Kong’s pro-democracy group enjoys full dialogue with the European Union and we must particularly appreciate and encourage Hong Kong’s efforts in combating climate change.  I voted in favour of this report and I particularly support the principle of non-interference into the internal affairs of Hong Kong, as well as the necessity to maintain the Basic Law as a guarantee of human rights, standards and fundamental political freedoms. We need to develop deeper and more active relations with Hong Kong as it has the potential to become an example of democratisation and liberalisation for other states in the east and south-east Asia region. In this way the EU can contribute to security in the region.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, it is an extraordinary thing when we think of the blood and treasure that was poured into Afghanistan in an attempt to keep out other countries one way or another, the huge damage done to that state because of rival powers attempting to gain influence there. The one thing that was never really properly tried, and which still has not been tried, is properly integrating Afghanistan into the world economy, allowing the institutions of private property and free contract to flourish there. We are still, I am afraid, playing these Great Game power politics which end up treating the ethnic groups and the tribes of Afghanistan as pawns rather than as constructs made up of individuals, each with their own interests in markets and success.  I hope that the time for Afghanistan will come. May I, while I am on my feet, take this opportunity to thank you, Mr President, for all the work you have done in the chair over the year, and wish you a very merry Christmas and extend the same to your officials and to the interpreters.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, we Europeans have been engaged in the state-building and development of Afghanistan for many years already. However, we have still failed to address the root causes of insecurity in the country. One month ago the Latvian Government decided to increase its military contingency in Afghanistan, which currently counts 24 military experts. But a further increase of military presence in Afghanistan will not get us anywhere if we do not address the issues of drug and mineral extraction that serves to finance the Taliban and other extremist organisations.  If you want our development efforts in Afghanistan to be successful we firstly need to contribute to security building and we need to take steps in preventing radicalisation, fighting corruption and establishing a strong and independent civil society. We should not forget that it is Afghanistan that should have the ownership of its economic and political processes. Therefore we should particularly support local initiatives and support the infrastructures to improve its citizens’ participation in political life.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, we were, I think, slow to grasp the enormity of what has been happening in Burma. It was a while before the stories of the atrocities suffered by the Rohingya people began to spread beyond newspapers that were either in Muslim-majority countries or Muslim-oriented in their readerships. But I think we have now got a sense of the magnitude of what is taking place.  I wonder whether we were slow because it challenged our western perceptions. We think of Buddhism as a kind of Californian, hippy, peaceful phenomenon and we tend in our recent coverage to think of Islam as militant rather than being on the receiving end of violence. It is what behavioural psychologists call the problem of agents and patients. We simultaneously struggle to see people as victims and as doers of violence. There is, at the moment, no worse human rights crisis on the planet and we cannot leave overwhelmed Bangladesh to try and deal with this issue bilaterally. If ever there was a case where we needed to step in, this is it.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report, which includes numerous references to the work of the UK’s Internet Watch Foundation (IWF), based in my constituency. However, as an IWF champion, I am deeply worried. They tell me an end to EU grants to the IWF and the UK Safer Internet Centre puts at risk the amount of child sexual abuse material they will be able to remove from the Internet. It risks the hotline that enables the public to report this material anonymously and unless alternative funds are urgently found, UK Safer Internet Day will end in 2019. We cannot allow this to happen. No one who voted for Brexit voted to make the internet more dangerous for children. The next tech-savvy generation face new dangerous challenges – cyber-bullying, online stranger danger and revenge porn. UK Safer Internet Day is the biggest Safer Internet Day in Europe, reaching nearly three million children and their parents each year. We must save it.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman!Of course, I voted in favor of the report which aims to step up efforts to protect children from sexual abuse, including the use of the Internet, and its criminalization.Especially since the sexual sphere is particularly sensitive to injuries resulting in serious disturbances affecting the whole human life.However, I would like to point out that it will not help to multiply legal regulations and directives without introducing an education to family life based on the principles of Christian ethics, where children should experience true love that cannot be equated with the sexual act.Unfortunately, the modernly propagated left-liberal sex education has pornographic and demoralizing features, leading to a distorted vision of sexuality separated from procreation and love, which results in psychosexual deviations.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this report and I must say that I did not understand my colleagues who did not vote - and there were many who did not vote. If we are talking about sexual abuse, if we are talking about this violence against children, I don't think we should be reluctant to make improvements to what exists. Now, of course, we have directives, we have national and European regulations, but we see that the figures are frightening. Child sexual abuse is on the rise and we need to find new mechanisms, European and national, to ensure, on the one hand, prevention, education of children, to block these sites - and I am glad that the report includes this. - which promotes images of sexually abused children. And we also need to build shelters and have the necessary infrastructure to take out the children who endure this sexual abuse and this violence in the family or at school. So I voted for this report and I hope there is a correct application.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! It is not gratifying that the committee has received an outstanding number of petitions from Romania in the last two years. Proportionally, only Greece approaches it. The nearly one hundred petitions a year mean that Romanian citizens are aware of their rights as EU citizens and the means to enforce them, and this is to be welcomed. However, the huge number of petitions also points out that there are systemic problems in Romania, which is why the Commission needs to pay special attention to them in certain areas. I do not believe that the rule of law and the guarantee of fundamental rights are to be held accountable only in Hungary and Poland, but that a mechanism is needed for all Member States. The number of petitions shows that in each Member State there are cases which may give rise to disputes and which cannot be resolved by the Member State authorities. What is certain is that if the selection of certain countries is nevertheless preferred, Romania should be included in the list.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I also voted on this report. I believe that we need to know the problems of the citizens. The Committee on Petitions can take over the petitions of European citizens. I would like to bring some figures here. My country is not in the first place. Romania is on the fourth place, it is not on the first place in the petitions, but - a relevant thing again - it has decreased. And perhaps most relevant is to look at which sector the petitions come from. In the first place as a field of activity, in 2016 the petitions were related to how the internal market works and not on the environment and not on justice and not on human rights. Therefore, I believe that we, the European Parliament, the Commission, the national authorities need to see what citizens are complaining about in the functioning of the internal market and call for the implementation of a fair market. After all, the rights of citizens are also related to the functioning of the internal market and I believe that this report brings improvements and we, MEPs, must say in our countries that there is this lever through which the citizen can complain about an unresolved issue in the country. to.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, it is not very common for a rapporteur to vote against his report. However, I voted against it for purely political reasons, to protest, as, as I mentioned in my speeches in the morning, in my initial report there was in paragraph 16 my explicit reference to the issue of German compensation that Germany owes to Greece. However, following an amendment by the European People's Party, the Socialist Group and the Liberals, the original paragraph 16 on German reparations was deleted, as was the corresponding reference in the explanatory memorandum. In the end, however, despite the efforts of these political groups, another explicit reference to the German war reparations that Germany owed to Greece remained in another part of the explanatory memorandum. So for the first time in a document of the European Union, which even bears my name, reference is made to German compensation. It is a first beginning and we will continue even stronger in 2018. Merry Christmas!

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, transport represents almost a quarter of Europe’s greenhouse gas emissions and is the main cause of air pollution in cities. This excellent report calls strongly for a change towards more sustainable modes of transport, a deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure and an ambitious action plan for the increasing use of electric vehicles. I agree entirely with these priorities so I was proud to vote for the report.  In addition, it was good that the amendment to the report, seeking to promote incentives to use mega trucks, was defeated as these are dangerous and unnecessary. However, it was disappointing that the point in the report on phasing out new emitting cars by 2035 was not approved. The European automotive industry must adapt much faster to mobility transition.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, in the European Union the transport sector represents a third of energy consumption and a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, it is one of the sectors that has seen its emissions increase the most since 1990. Therefore, moving towards a sustainable mobility model is a fundamental task. But, again, we have to be careful about greenwashing. With those who use the fight against climate change to wash their image. The use of misnamed natural gas and some biofuels does not represent an adequate solution at all. These fuels only perpetuate the extractivist model and anchor us to a global model with excessive need or dependence on transport. For this reason, we must massively develop public transport and improve rail transport, also improve intermodality and digitization of the sector and include externalities with the principle of "Who pollutes, pays". These tools are some of the necessary measures so that we can breathe less polluted air.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, in my capacity as a member of the TRAN Commission, but also of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I voted in favor of this report. There are many things that bring improvements. We all know that transport has effects on the competitiveness of the economy in our countries and on the internal market. At the same time, I was glad that the report focused on urban transport and I believe - and I also said in plenary - that it is necessary to start from there, with urban transport, to switch from a petrol fuel. for cars and electric vehicles. I am also pleased with the Commissioner's position and the report also sets out what was contained in the 2011 White Paper on the transition to green transport: taking into account the impact on small and medium-sized enterprises. , to invest in technology and research, to have car parks, as well as the necessary infrastructure for power supply and, in this way, to reach a competitive and clean economy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sa tuarascáil seo. Ach bíodh sin ráite, is dóigh liom go bhfuil freagracht mhór ar an Aontas ó thaobh troid i gcoinne athrú aeráide agus ár n-astaíochtaí a íoslaghdú agus dár ndóigh, tá mórán déanta againn cheana féin. Bhíos i bPáras dhá bhliain ó shin, i gcomhair shíniú Chomhaontú Pháras, mar ar thug gach tír beagnach ar domhan gealltanas an t-ardú teochta a choimeád faoi dhá chéim, i gcoinne leibhéal aimsir na Réabhlóide Tionsclaíche agus síos go dtí 1.5 céim, más féidir. Tá ról lárnach ag an iompar sa cheist seo agus is dóigh liom gur féidir, ar a laghad, astaíochtaí gáis ceaptha teasa a laghdú seasca faoin gcéad idir seo agus 2050. Beidh nuálaíocht an-tábhachtach dó sin agus fáiltím roimh mhodhanna iompair éifeachtúla nua chun dícharbónú iompair a bhaint amach.  Agus mar fhocal scoir, níl mé chun amhrán Gaelach a chasadh, ach Nollaig Shona do gach uile dhuine, agus míle buíochas as ucht an chomhoibrithe uaitse agus na hoifigigh timpeall ort i rith na bliana.  I might be the last speaker this year, but hopefully I am not the least.
